talk.start.para: —by leave—I claim to have been misrepresented. In his speech concluding the second reading debate on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, Senator Bolkus claimed that I, presumably as Attorney-General in the Fraser Government, had no regard for the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. That is totally untrue. If Senator Bolkus had really made a careful study of it he would have known it to be untrue. Presumably, these words were thrown away quite gratuitously.

para.tab: The record shows that it was the Fraser Government—and it was my responsibility as the Attorney-General in that Government—which took the steps required to ratify the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights by Australia. That was not something that had been achieved by the Whitlam Labor Government. It certainly was a matter which was high on the agenda of the Fraser Government. It was something that required a great deal of negotiation and discussion with the States to ensure that Australian laws—State and Federal—were in order so that we could make that ratification. After that process, as a government, we duly ratified the International Covenant and gave further effect to its operation in Australia by establishing the Human Rights Commission. That body was set up shortly afterwards.

In addition to this record of the Fraser Government and myself as Attorney-General in relation to human rights and civil liberties, we also introduced and passed through this Parliament, after a great deal of debate and lengthy consideration, the Freedom of Information Act. We also brought into operation the important legislation in relation to administrative review and the requirement of public servants and Ministers to give reasons for their decisions. speech.para: As was mentioned by Senator Hill, we have had the extraordinary situation of a Bill being introduced into this place with 23 clauses and then some 37 amendments, followed by another 13 or so amendments. This Bill has been guillotined by the Labor Party, in conjunction with the Australian Democrats, in order to race something through, the effect of which would be to limit freedom of political expression and freedom of speech in this country.

para.tab: I would be interested to know what the Democrats intend to do about this. I refer to a letter sent to me by the previous Leader of the Democrats, Senator Powell, on 8 August in which, amongst other things, she said:
Clearly the Government has finally accepted that it will not get its original proposal through and is prepared to stand by its commitment to disclosure.
In light of this we can now act with regard to those sections of the Bill relating to political advertising.

I would ask that the Opposition join with us to send the question of political advertising to a Senate Committee. Obviously as political advertising will not be banned the Democrats wish to pursue our truth in advertising amendments.

I will be fascinated to see the Democrats' response, because this is what Senator Coulter seized upon to beat Senator Powell about the head with when he took over the leadership of his Party. It was something that was very important to individual Democrats in society and to the loose-knit interest groups that support the Australian Democrats. To try to rectify the position that Senator Powell found herself in, she made the remark to me in writing that `political advertising will not be banned', and now we have the Democrats coming in here making a deal with Senator Bolkus and the Labor Party to ban political advertising.

talk.start.para: —I support Senator Parer's motion because there is no doubt that there is a clear need to split the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill into two Bills. There cannot be proper consideration of these two quite disparate matters in the present Bill, as is evidenced by the extraordinary position changing of the Australian Democrats, which clearly relates to deal-doing rather than the merits of the issue. The merits of this case are quite clear, and the Opposition has stated that it is in favour of improving the political reporting of funding. There has been no resiling from the position that was outlined by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson).

para.tab: The other part of the Bill, which is clearly and distinctly separate, is one on which there is universal disagreement amongst the great bulk of Australians, judging not only from opinion polls but also from the representations made by interest groups, quite apart from the human rights considerations raised by a Commissioner of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. There is no doubt that the part of the Bill which relates to banning of political advertising does not have universal support. It is so strongly opposed by the Opposition that we wished to state how strongly we did oppose it by sitting here all night, in view of the undemocratic way in which the Government had put a guillotine on a Bill that relates to basic fundamental principles of democracy.

As has been pointed out, there is no doubt that the Australian Democrats at one stage purported to support the view that the Bill should be split and, as Senator Parer said, that political advertising would not be banned. This underlines the point that former Senator Puplick made in this place following another such remarkable change of heart by the Democrats. He said that he agreed totally with the view that the Australian Democrats could not be bought, because it was evident that they could only be hired by the hour.

In this case they—with the honourable exception, once again, of Senator Sowada—have been hired by the hour by the Labor Party for the purpose of getting this disgraceful legislation through this place, in exchange for 50 minutes of free time on television. I suppose that we should look at that free time and say, `Well, if the talking head is going to be Senator Coulter's, that could well be to our advantage'. But
they will be getting 50 minutes of free television advertising time—which they could not afford to buy because they do not have that kind of public support—because of the nature of the deal that they have done with the Labor Party to support this proposition. Of course, that is only if the legislation does succeed in any court challenge.

There is no doubt that the Australian Democrats once again have changed their position. I outlined earlier, during the second reading debate, how former senators Macklin and Colin Mason, both Deputy Leaders of that Party, strongly supported the idea of political advertising but simply wanted to make certain that people involved in political advertising had the same burden as the rest of the community to make their advertising honest. One can sympathise with their objectives, even though their methods of achieving it may have been open to some discussion.

In the circumstances, I simply ask the Australian Democrats to go back once again to the principles of their Party, as enunciated by previous leaders and previous deputy leaders, and to support the motion now put up by Senator Parer.

talk.start.para: —I support the motion that has been moved by Senator Parer. I think this motion is capable of being supported irrespective of the view that one might take on the question of a ban on electronic media advertising.

para.tab: The two matters that are contained in the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, which Senator Parer seeks to divide, are disparate matters: one matter deals with the question of political advertising on the electronic media; and the other, the broad aspect of the Bill, deals with the question of disclosure of donations to political parties and candidates.

Clearly, the money that is paid to political candidates and to political parties can be used in a variety of ways. It can be used to support campaigns in other than the electronic media and, indeed, is so used and will be increasingly used if the political broadcasting provisions relating to the electronic media pass the Senate. The question of the overall expenditure of public and private moneys on political campaigns is a major concern of mine, whether that be through the electronic media or by other means; for example, if the political broadcasts aspect of the Bill goes through, by innumerable other means which have been canvassed during the second reading debate.

As a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, which dealt with this issue some time ago and which went through all the aspects of political broadcasting and political advertising, I must say that I can see a difference between one aspect of the Bill and the other aspect. I mention that because those of us who were on that Committee know full well that considerable amounts of money were injected into party organisations which were not overtly for the campaign process but were utilised through third parties and by political parties, apart from the periods of the election campaign.

It is very important that we see the difference between these two particular matters. As I said, irrespective of one's view on the issues, one can come to the logical conclusion that the two matters are disparate and, therefore, that the motion by Senator Parer is worthy of support. I support the motion.

talk.start.para: —I would welcome the opportunity to debate, as a talking head, with Senator Baume any time because if the logic which he used in his remarks a few moments ago is any indication, he would lose hands down.
—What has this got to do with the motion?

—Senator Macdonald is simply demonstrating his lack of logic and is joining with his colleague. Senator Baume mentioned specifically former senators Macklin and Mason in relation to repeated attempts to get truth in political advertising. That was what they were attempting to do. That was consistently opposed by both the Government and the Opposition.

para.tab: We have before us an alternative process—and this is what Senator Baume does not understand or does not want to understand—which moves us towards more honesty in advertising, because, through the mechanism of talking heads which must address the camera for a minimum of two minutes, we are more likely to get truth in political advertising.

Contrary to the conclusion Senator Baume has drawn, what we are doing is perfectly consistent with what our former senators said, but it is achieved through a different mechanism. We are still committed to getting the greatest degree of truth and honesty in political advertising that we possibly can and to raising the level of political debate through television, which is absolutely abysmal. If the Opposition does not accept that, it simply cannot recognise proper and appropriate debate from the poor quality material which passes for political debate on our television screens.

The argument was put by Senator Baume in a way which actually proves my point up to the hilt. He said that we are supporting this legislation because we will get more advertising under this regime than we could afford. In other words, he is saying that we are not entitled to the 11 per cent—which is related to the amount of support at the last election, and which under a fully democratic system would be the amount of advertising to which we would be properly and democratically entitled—because we could not afford it. That, of course, goes right to the heart of the matter.

The Opposition can afford it. It will get more political advertising and that is precisely what it wants to do—to exclude the legitimate rights of candidates and parties because they simply cannot afford to buy the time on television. C
ontrary to Senator Baume supporting his argument, what he said in fact exactly supports the argument that I have been putting.

talk.start.para: —What support did you get in the House of Representatives?

Senator Baume, of course, comes from a party which locks itself in and is quite incapable of moving in relation to the change of events. Things have moved on considerably since that statement was made. There has been consideration by the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures. The Government has substantially changed its legislation and in the present context we find that we can indeed support this legislation. I am reminded of an article by Ross Gittins in today's

Sydney Morning Herald

talk.start.para: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion No. 32 standing in my name, I move:

para.tab: That it be an instruction to the committee of the whole on the bill that:
(a)the committee divide the bill so as to incorporate into two separate bills the provisions relating to political broadcasts and the provisions relating to disclosure of political donations; and
(b)the committee report the bills separately.

speech.para: The purpose of giving an instruction to the Committee of the Whole to split the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 is that it is our view that this Bill is made up of two parts which clearly can be differentiated. One is the ban on advertising on television and radio. The other one is in relation to disclosure of donations to political parties. Right from the beginning, it has been the consistent view of the Opposition that under no circumstances would we support anything that would in any way infringe on the freedom of political expression and freedom of speech in this country.

para.tab: It was supposedly the view of the Australian Democrats as well. To the credit of Senator Sowada, I know that she has stuck to her guns on that principle. I noted that in the evidence given to the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures it was spelt out by Senator Sowada, representing the Democrats—

talk.start.para: —New South Wales branch as campaign director.

—I stand corrected. It was the view of Senator Sowada, as compared with my own submission which was in fact the view of the Liberal and National parties. It is our view that this Bill should be split in the Committee of the Whole and that anything which relates to the ban on political advertising in Australia should be thrown out.

para.tab: With regard to disclosure, from the beginning the coalition has made it quite clear, and we have been absolutely consistent, that we will support disclosure of donations to political parties on the condition that there is sufficient protection against intimidation by either a hostile government or third parties against a donor and that a donor is protected against coercion to make a donation to a political party.

talk.start.para: —That is not without some background, irrespective of the remarks of Senator Schacht, because we all saw what happened in Western Australia at the famous gold lunch. No-one would believe that coercion was not involved.

para.tab: The other aspect is that the donations to political parties should be fair and equitable as regards the donors to those political parties. In the evidence provided to the Select Committee, it was patently obvious that the Australian Labor Party, because it is the political arm of the trade union movement, has substantial benefits available to it that are not available to any other political party in this country. The reason for that is the affiliation fees paid to the Labor Party. I know that the Labor Party disputes this figure, but on my own calculation it would appear that some $4m to $5m goes into Labor Party coffers.

talk.start.para: —I thought you said $45m.

—No, $4m to $5m goes into the coffers from affiliation fees. The reason why the unions affiliate is to enable them to influence policy and get ready access to Ministers. That was spelt out very clearly in the Cooke report relating to when the clerks union in Queensland decided to affiliate with the ALP—at a meeting, I might say, which Wayne Goss attended. He encouraged them to affiliate, simply to get the $30,000, I presume; but it also guaranteed them access to Ministers and an influence on policy.

para.tab: The other aspect is that the unions have a very protected position in our society in that any other investment by anyone else in the community is subject to normal taxation—land tax, capital gains tax and so on. These days the unions are no longer just organisations to look after their members; they have become very big business. They own buildings in the CBD, they own properties around the country and they have investments.

talk.start.para: —What about BHP?

—I am delighted to hear Senator Schacht say that. If BHP does—I do not know—it pays tax; if it gives a donation, it is after tax money.
The trade union movement does not pay tax, does not pay capital gains tax, does not pay State land tax and can make donations to the ALP.
—The unions tell their members; it is published every year.
—Senator Schacht has vocal diarrhoea. I wish he would give me some chance to be able to be heard.

Opposition senators interjecting

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)

talk.start.para: —I was talking about fair and equitable contributions by donors to all political parties. The Labor Party has a decided advantage because it is simply the political arm of the trade union movement which has an awful lot of benefits not available to every other citizen in this society.

para.tab: In summary, the Opposition believes that the Bill should be split in the committee stage. We are totally opposed to anything that would infringe on political freedoms and freedom of speech in this country. It is very important that the young people of this country do not get themselves into a position where a government, as this Government is now doing, introduces a Bill which will not just stifle but kill all dissent during an election campaign. It would prevent anyone, whether they be in a Federal, State or local election, taking out an advertisement on a radio station. Radio advertising is the cheapest form of advertising within all of the media groups. It is cheaper than newspaper advertising and it is a lot cheaper than television advertising.

The Government, with the concurrence of the Democrats, is preventing people from taking out an advertisement during election campaigns. The Government will argue that advertisements can be taken out at other times of the year. What good is that? Who is interested in a person who might be running for the local shire or the local council outside an election campaign?

I refer to disclosure. The Opposition will fully embrace disclosure, as made very clear by Dr Hewson. Irrespective of what Senator Coulter says about waffling, we have made that very clear from the outset. We have not deviated one bit. I wish I could say the same for the Democrats. The Democrats deviated not just last month or last week but deviate on a daily basis. It is impossible to understand the direction in which the Democrats are going. I notice that some of the proposals that the Democrats are putting, or not accepting from the Opposition point of view, do not even follow their policy. What does it all mean? It is totally beyond me.

talk.start.para: —I support Senator Parer's motion to split the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill in the committee stage. In doing so, I ask the Australian Democrats—I hope that they will respond—why it is so necessary to deal with both aspects of the Bill at this particular time. The Democrats, more than I, would be aware of the flood of protests that are coming into their offices at this very moment from people who are very concerned about the banning of free speech in this community. The protests are starting to flood in, as the Democrats would be aware.

para.tab: It behoves Senator Kernot as a Queenslander to take heed of what the Queenslanders are saying. It just might be that all of those people who are protesting to the Democrats have a point. Why the unholy rush to deal with the Bill by 7.30 p.m. today? Why could it not be put off so that Senator Kernot could consider those arguments, could consider the protests that have been made and could consider whether, possibly, some of the matters raised in the debate last night have some validity? She could look at it over Christmas and come back and deal with it in January, February or March. Why will she not do that? If the Democrats want to deal with the political disclosure part of the Bill, that is fine; let us do that today. We will deal with the disclosure part, providing, as Senator Parer says, it is fair and equitable and there is no intimidation. Let us deal with it today. Why does this other matter have to go?

It is very hard for Senator Kernot to hear me because ever since the Senate started at 10 o'clock this morning Senator Bolkus has been sitting next to Senator Kernot and Senator Coulter—he has spent more time sitting there than he has spent sitting in his own seat—trying to intimidate them. As if that has not been good enough, we have also had the team of heavyweights. Senator Schacht has been doing the same thing. I have even seen Senator Reynolds doing her bit and trying to intimidate and coerce this weak, pitiful little lot.

The sooner the Democrats get a leader of some principle—someone like Senator Sowada, who has the principle and the guts to stand up for what she believes in and for what her Party used to believe in, for what Don Chipp, Michael Macklin and Janine Haines used to believe in; a bit of fairness, truth and thought for democracy and free speech in this community—the better they will be.

I ask the Democrats again: why the rush on the Bill to ban advertisements? Why the rush on the Bill to ban free speech? Let it go until January or February. They should consider all the protests that their supporters are now pouring into their offices. There may be something in them. If Senator Coulter took a little time to read them he might understand them better. Why do not the Democrats put it off and deal with it separately in the New Year? Let us deal with the disclosure part today. We agree with Senator Kernot. She has convinced Australia. She did not need to convince us because we always believed in that.

talk.start.para: —Dr Hewson said that.

—Dr Hewson said that in his first press conference, did he not? Of course, he did. Let us go ahead and do that. I invite the Democrats—in fact, I urge them, and insist that we do—to deal with the disclosure part today.

para.tab: Maybe just one of those protests that Senator Kernot's supporters have made to her today has some merit. Why can she not have a look at them? What is the desperate hurry? Are we about to have another election? Is there another election in the wind? Has it got to be done before Christmas? The way this Government is being run, one can understand that there will not be an election for as many months and as many years as it can manage. Let us put it off. Let us look at it a bit more calmly. Let us look at the protests that have been made to Senator Kernot's office. Let us deal with it in the calm light of the New Year. Let us pass the disclosure section of the Bill today, as Senator Parer says—I insist upon that—but let us put the other one off. Why will the Democrats not do that?

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak against Senator Parer's motion and also to set the record straight on a few of the outrageous statements made by Senator Macdonald. For the benefit of all those people listening who cannot see what is happening within this chamber, who have to rely on Senator Macdonald's misrepresentations, I want to put on the record the fact that I have been sitting here and I have been receiving representations from Senator Bolkus. When that finished, I received representations from Senator Olsen. I find myself literally in a balance of power situation in the eye of the storm. I do not resile from that.

para.tab: I have met with Senator Reynolds and, because honourable senators could not hear what Senator Reynolds said to me, I will tell them that I was discussing the work of another select committee that I serve on. I am happy for people to know that not only do I have to work on this matter today, but at lunch time I have to go off and do my work on the 0055 committee. Senator Calvert from the Liberal side has been over here talking to us as well. This is not one-sided. Everybody wants to put a point of view to us. We are accustomed to that. Senator Walters has been particularly helpful in providing me with a copy of some amendments. This is not one-sided, so Senator Macdonald should not misrepresent the issue.

I would like people who are listening to know that we have spent hours and hours meeting with the Opposition as well as the Government in discussing all sets of amendments on this legislation. Senator Macdonald asks, `Why the rush?'. I said last night and I repeat today: we have listened to evidence on this matter for months. We have had hundreds of submissions. They have dealt with free time and they have dealt with the majority of the issues raised in this legislation.

talk.start.para: —What about these amendments that came in yesterday?

—The amendments may have come in but the substance of them has been debated. I just want to point to Senator Macdonald's comments about all of our supporters suddenly contacting us and faxing us. Senator Macdonald well knows that the President of the Liberal Party in Queensland, Professor Goldsworthy, has put out a press release. In that press release is the dishonest representation of our commitment to accept an increase in Senate public funding. I said last night that we stated on 9 April that we would not accept an increase in Senate public funding levels. Nevertheless, Professor Goldsworthy's press release makes this statement. It is in response to Professor Goldsworthy's press release and the list of fax numbers and telephone numbers on the bottom of it that the Opposition supporters and donors are faxing us—not Democrat supporters. Our supporters do not receive Professor Goldsworthy's press releases.

para.tab: I am not intimidated by speaking to the Minister or to the shadow senator who is responsible for the carriage of this Bill. I am happy to listen to all points of view in the debate, and we have some way to go towards finding common ground with the Government and the Opposition on some very important amendments.

This guillotine is again a misrepresentation. It is a guillotine, but the Opposition is saying that this is the most important piece of legislation on the books of this Parliament. I said last night—and I will repeat it—that I felt very passionately about the future of telecommunications in this country. The Opposition did not care less. It agreed with the Government. We were restructuring the whole telecommunications industry, there were massive ramifications for Australian consumers, and we gave that about eight hours debate. That is the Opposition's priority; this is my priority. I do not see why the Opposition would say that this is the most important matter.

talk.start.para: —They are banning free speech.

—It is not free speech. I said last night that the sort of manipulative, intimidating, deceptive, sloganising advertisements that we see on television during election campaigns are a threat to democracy because they prohibit rational speech and thought. They do not assist logical, reasoned and informed votes.

—I support the motion moved by my colleague Senator Parer and supported by Senator Macdonald. A number of issues have emerged which, in my view, make it very important that the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill be split so that these issues can be effectively debated. The first issue emerging as a result of the debate last night is that only those of us on this side of the chamber seem to know just what is the value of the free time the granting of which we are demanding in this Bill.
—Speak to the motion.

—Based on the information that I have received from the industry, I have put the view that the total cost of this free time—and this is the total cost to the TV companies, Senator Kernot—is $18m; and the Australian Democrats' share of this largesse is $1.8m. I have put these figures to Senator Coulter and Senator Kernot, and I have asked them to come into this chamber and disprove them. We have had two or three speeches from Senator Kernot and a couple from Senator Coulter, but each time they have ducked and weaved on the issue. I see that Senator Bolkus is over there again speaking to the Australian Democrats.

para.tab: This Bill is about disclosure; this Bill is about political advertising. Why can the Australian Democrats not officially disclose the benefit that they will be receiving under this Bill—a benefit which is unique to the Australian Democrats compared with any other political parties and interest groups, and particularly the smaller political parties? This is a unique benefit that Senator Kernot, Senator Coulter and their colleagues are about to give themselves. We want the Democrats and the Government to disclose this massive benefit.

I have put figures before this Senate now for the third time—I have asked Senator Kernot to come out and refute them, and she has not been prepared to do it—to support the proposition that as a result of this Bill the Australian Democrats will receive a fourfold to fivefold increase in political advertising funding in the next election compared with the March 1990 election. It is a massive benefit. We have now been setting out the figures for the last 15 to 16 hours, and each time Senator Kernot has come into this chamber she has ducked the issue and avoided disclosing the Australian Democrats' own figures on the benefit that they will receive as a result of this Bill. They will be receiving, on my figures, a massive benefit.

The other issue to which I wish to speak in relation to this motion is this vexed question to which we are still awaiting a proper answer: why the rush? Senator Kernot says that she has had plenty of time to review the evidence, and I think that is a fair enough point—she has had plenty of time to review the evidence. She has been in constant consultation with Senator Bolkus on this matter and there is no argument that, as a result, she has been fully informed and fully briefed on the Government's Bill and its amendments.

But I ask Senator Kernot and Senator Coulter: has there been proper consultation with all those interest groups out there who will be affected by this Bill, who will not get the Democrats' $1.8m benefit? Have they had a chance to see the impact this Bill will have on them? The answer, for those who are listening to the radio broadcast, is no.

Those who are tuning in to this debate do not know what is involved in this Bill; they do not know of its impact on the interest groups and political parties that they are involved with. If they wish to raise a major issue of importance in a State or Federal election, the putting of their views before the public in the vital election period will be greatly restrained as a result of this Labor Party-Democrats Bill.

So I say to Senator Kernot and Senator Coulter that these groups have not been properly informed. They have not had time to consider these Bills. That is why the Democrats are rushing this Bill through. If this Bill is guillotined through the chamber with the assistance of the Australian Democrats, they will be reaping the whirlwind.

talk.start.para: —I rise to oppose this motion.
—Hang on, Nick is coming to tell you what to say.

—He certainly does not need to tell me what to say. I will address immediately the nefarious claims made by Senator Kemp. He talks of the opportunity to be properly informed. If we were to rely upon the sort of communication to interest groups from, and initiated by, the coalition, we would find that those interest groups would be totally misinformed. The most recent correspondence that interest groups received has claimed that there will be a total ban on advertising and that they will not have any opportunity at all to participate in presenting political information. The fact is that they will have two years and 337 days in which to place their case. During the election campaign they will also have the opportunity, as does everybody—
—This came out last night.

—Whatever came out of Senator Macdonald's contribution is inaccurate, ill-informed and totally misguided. If the Opposition gives interest groups that sort of information, of course they will get the wrong end of the stick. Even during the election campaign period all interest groups will have the opportunity to engage in talkback radio and news and current affairs programs and use billboards and even town criers—you name it. They will not be restricted in their opportunity to present their point of view.

para.tab: Let us have a look at some of the other incredible assumptions the coalition has made in reaching these conclusions, the assumptions that Senator Kemp and his ilk have used as a foundation for their ill-advised assertions and accusations. The main assumption that Senator Kemp asked us to address today is the value of the time made available in this so-called talking heads exhibition. What is the value of two minutes of broadcast time in which there is no opportunity to play jingles and generally conduct the song and dance that we see in other advertisements in the commercial sphere at the moment? What is the value of that time? We do not have the opportunity to use any of the sophisticated production techniques which are seen in commercial advertising.

talk.start.para: —That is not the question.

—That is the question. What is that time worth? The Opposition has not been able to address what it is worth. What is it worth to be provided with two minutes of broadcast time? It is not advertising time; it is time to make an announcement. Margaret Thatcher placed no value on the time because she did not even use the time. She found it inconvenient; she found it not worth anything.

para.tab: Senator Kemp wants to put a monetary value on that time. He is misguided. He continues to misguide the people who listen to this debate and he continues to misguide the ventriloquist dummies that he has stringing along at the end of fax machines trying to influence those people who are taking part in this debate at the moment. The ventriloquist dummies have danced to the tune of Senator Kemp and have provided very misguided, ill-informed reactions to this issue. If we rely on Senator Kemp to inform us, we will never know what we are talking about.

talk.start.para: —I was not going to rise to discuss this motion, but after the contribution from Senator Bell I feel I have to. The proposition that we in the coalition have put is that the Australian Democrats will get a windfall advertising bonus of $1.5m to $1.8m in a Federal election campaign. We have asked the Democrats to quantify that. We have asked them to tell us exactly what the windfall will be that they will get by virtue of this Bill—the free advertising that they would never have been able to afford before. Time and time again, we on this side of the chamber have asked that question of the Democrats because we believe that they must first answer that question and establish their bona fides before we can proceed to a proper and in-depth discussion of the provisions of this Bill.

para.tab: Senator Bell attempted to skirt around the issue yet again by not talking about the monetary worth of the free advertising the Democrats are getting—the monetary worth of this windfall that they will get through the deal they have done with the Government—instead, he decided to try to talk about the value of it.

talk.start.para: —The real value of it.

—The real value of it, he says. He does not address how much they have saved or how much free advertising they have received. He tries to say, `Oh well, you know, it is not really as important as you would like us to believe', but I tell you what, I bet Senator Bell and his colleagues in the Democrats will use every single minute of it. That is the real worth of this Bill to the Democrats: the fact that it gives them $1.5m to $1.8m of windfall advertising that they would certainly never be able to afford themselves. The fact that they are incapable of denying it, the fact that they try to skirt around it and try sophistry, as we have just heard from Senator Bell, is the most poignant example yet of how true our arguments are.

para.tab: Senator Bell did not feel that he was capable of getting up and arguing against it rationally and logically and telling the truth. He could not tell the truth. He had to look at something other than the truth. He had to try to worm his way out. That is typical of the Democrats. We have seen them worm their way out of every other position they have ever been in. We have seen them worm their way out of the statements laid down by their leader and founder, former Senator Chipp; we have seen them worm their way out of Senator Macklin's position on this; we have seen them worm their way out of Senator McLean's position on guillotines; and now we find Senator Bell refusing to answer the question.

Is not the depth to which these people have sunk disgraceful? They come into this chamber and support a Bill on the basis of a deal that they have done with the Government to get their $1.5m of free advertising. They have prostituted and sold short the democratic rights of 17 million Australians so they can get their $1.5m of free advertising. It is disgraceful, it is appalling and it debases the proceedings of this Parliament that Senator Bell does not have the honesty even to attempt to answer the arguments we have put to him. The more the Democrats try to worm their way out of it, the deeper they find themselves in the sewer of their own political depravity. That is why their support in the electorate is shrinking every day—because people are waking up to the fact that this Party which sits to my left is nothing but a party of frauds.

. Senators are asked not to be wide-ranging in their remarks, but to relate their remarks to the two aspects of the motion before us, about the division of the Bill and about reporting the Bill separately from the Committee of the Whole.

Hansard
of the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures the evidence given by Mr Sherry of his frank intimidation by union members, and the reallocation of funds that were meant for the wives and children of striking unionists to the Labor Party funds by the ACTU and the Trades and Labour Council in Queensland. speech.para: The material I have uncovered during the course of the book on the SEQEB dispute indicates that, while the SEQEB strike funds were collected for the sacked workers and their families, a great deal of the money that was collected simply did not reach the striking families.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)
—Senator Schacht, I remind you that before I called on Senator Walters I drew not only her attention but also the whole Senate's attention to the procedural motion. talk.start.para: —Senator Schacht, the Chairman of this Committee, does not want the public to know about and understand this matter. I particularly said that the division of this Bill into disclosures of money going to political parties and the ban on broadcasting is essential because we cannot overcome abuse by the Labor Party in relation to disclosures. para.tab: This is why the Bill should be divided—so that we can clearly look on the one hand at the disclosures and, on the other hand, at the ban on political broadcasting. They are two totally different things.

Let me just talk about the ban on political broadcasting. Despite what Senator Bell said on air this morning, no amendments have yet been passed and, as the Bill presently stands, the ban lasts for the whole of the year. Senator Bell, on air this morning, absolutely misinterpreted the Bill we are presently debating.

It is important for people to understand just what the Labor Party wants. It has said that at no time during the year can anyone place an advertisement on radio or television in any way critical of the Government, of the Opposition or of any other party. Not only that, but no organisation, no charity, no individual, no-one representing Federal, State or local government, can put any advertisement in the electronic media that could even be interpreted as trying to say something critical of any political party.

In Australia we are used to complete freedom. We have never known governments such as those in the USSR or the totalitarian regimes that Senator Schacht lauds and thinks are so wonderful. Here we have known complete freedom of our press, complete freedom of speech and complete democracy—not the Labor democracy I have spoken about so many times in this place. Labor democracy is no democracy at all. There is a secret ballot in the party room but, because the factions will not allow the system to work, after the secret ballot people are forced to show their vote to factional members to prove that they have voted the way their faction tells them. That is Labor democracy. We on this side of the chamber will have nothing to do with it.

We will be content so long as the people out there understand just what this Government is attempting to do. It will be yet another reason to throw this Government out at the next election. The Government is saying that no-one will be allowed to buy advertising time, but the media—the radio stations, the television stations, the ABC—will pay for six minutes of advertisements a day on television. Who do people reckon pays the ABC bill? The taxpayers pay it. The taxpayers will pay for six minutes every day. The commercial stations will be forced by this Government to donate part of their time for these so-called free advertisements.

That is the sort of democracy we look at when we look at the Government opposite us. Not only is the Government content with bringing down the economy of this country, with a million unemployed, with the recession we had to have—and we are now getting into the depression we had to have—but also it is willing to take away the freedoms that this country holds so dear.

talk.start.para: —I wish to say a few words mainly in response to the remarks made by Senator Walters about the operation of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures on the Bill and, in particular, the evidence given by Mr Sherry.

para.tab: I make it quite clear that I agreed with Mr Sherry coming to give evidence before the Committee. That was not a unanimous decision of the Committee. talk.start.para: —I want to address the question of why it is important to split the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991. The material I want to raise goes to the question as to whether one part of this Bill—that dealing with political advertising, the banning thereof and the allocation of so-called free time—is ultra vires the Constitution.

para.tab: There are three important points that need to be addressed in looking at the subject matter. First, is the time that is confiscated from the commercial television stations property? Secondly, if it is property, has there been an acquisition of it by either the Commonwealth or another party? Thirdly, if there has been such an acquisition of the property, has it been on just terms? Those reasons are pertinent because of section 51(xxxi) of the Constitution. Section 51 states:

speech.para: The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to:-

para.tab: (xxxi) the acquisition of property on just terms from any State or person for any purpose in respect of which the Parliament has power to make laws.

speech.para: That becomes the only relevant clause in the Constitution, and the only clause that can give power for this legislation, because of the case law. It is quite clear. First, I refer to the case of Clunies Ross v. the Commonwealth, reported at 155 CLR. In that case, the joint judgment of the six judges of the High Court declared:

The plenary grant of legislative power contained in section 51(xxxi) has assumed the status of constitutional guarantee of just terms, as established in the Minister for the Army v. Dalziel (1944). It is to be given the liberal construction appropriate to such a constitutional provision.

The case cited is the Attorney-General v. Schmidt. The most up-to-date case, decided on only 29 October 1991, is the case of Peverill v. Health Insurance Commission, heard in the Federal Court of Australia by Burchett J., who said:
To construe a constitutional guarantee narrowly would be by that to diminish it and the Constitution. Repeatedly, and in various forms, this fundamental principle is laid down in the cases.

He goes on to cite cases where that has been determined. What he is saying is that section 51 (xxxi) is to be construed as a guarantee and that, further, it is to be construed in a liberal way. As we go through the case law we will see that `property' is to be widely interpreted, not simply in terms of whether it is an estate in fee simple or something of the like.

para.tab: The case law also establishes that one may not avoid the guarantee by using a circuitous method and using a statute which one believes could avoid that guarantee. Isaacs J., in a 1926 case, Commonwealth and Commonwealth Oil Refineries Ltd v. South Australia, states that, if a statute transgresses a constitutional prohibition either specifically or in a circuitous manner, then it will be struck down as well.

So there are three important things that we have established: first, that the Constitution implies a guarantee; secondly, that the word `property' is to be broadly construed, that is, liberally construed; and, thirdly, that one may not avoid the guarantee by using a circuitous method and using a statute which one believes could avoid that guarantee.

Isaacs J. said that the test to be applied to the impugned legislation is the substance of the operation of the statute rather than merely its form. But the pivotal case remains the Minister of State for the Army v. Dalziel, the 1944 case that I mentioned previously. In that case, Latham, the then Chief Justice, made the statement:

speech.para: The provision in the Constitution is plainly intended for the protection of the subject, and should be liberally interpreted.
Rich J. in the same case went on to say:

What we are concerned with is not a private document creating rights inter partes, but a Constitution containing a provision of a fundamental character designed to protect citizens from being deprived of their property by the Sovereign State except upon just terms.

The meaning of property in such a connection must be determined upon general principles of jurisprudence, not by the artificial refinements of any particular legal system or by reference to Sheppard's Touchstone. The language used is perfectly general. It says `the acquisition of property'; it is not restricted to acquisition by particular methods or of particular types of interest, nor to particular types of property. It extends to any acquisition of any interest in any property. It authorises such acquisition, but it expressly imposes two conditions on every such acquisition. It must be upon just terms and it must be for `a purpose in respect of which the Parliament has power to make the laws'.

para.tab: The important thing here is that by any definition the property which is being acquired by the Commonwealth to be handed over to a third party, that is, in this case, the Democrats, the Labor Party, or indeed the Liberal Party for that matter, is property which has been seized, which has been acquired. The point that it has been acquired is borne out by the fact that it is passed over to somebody else to use and do something with. When one looks at whether or not there are just terms provided for this acquisition, one must answer no.

To recap, so we understand, we have property which is being acquired—and, in the words of the Constitution and the case law interpretation, it may only be so acquired on just terms. If it fails that test, it is ultra vires the Constitution and it fails. In other words, the deal that has been put together by the Democrats with the Labor Party—that they, in return for whatever it is they have agreed to, get their talking heads commercials free to them but at the expense of somebody else in the run-up to the election—is ultra vires and not valid legislation.

talk.start.para: —That is rubbish. That is total rubbish.

—The Minister glibly says it is rubbish, but he is not willing to have it tested. He is not willing to have the Bill separated so that we can look at the validity of one and leave the other. Dr Hewson said right from the beginning that we were in favour of disclosure when it was on fair and just terms. That is still our position. We would like to deal with the Bill in those terms. But there is also good evidence that the

speech.para: Bill, which is the vehicle which has allowed the Labor Party to do a deal with the Democrats, is in fact not valid. It is something that ought to be tested, and it ought to be examined and discussed and not guillotined through this Parliament.

para.tab: Look again at the case of Minister of State for the Army v. Dalziel. I have read the portion of Latham C.J. and Rich J. Mr Justice Burchett, in the case that I have mentioned, dated 29 October 1991, says quite clearly that he takes that case to mean:

speech.para: . . . s. 51(xxxi) is not to be confined pedantically to the taking of title by the Commonwealth to some specific estate or interest in land recognized at law or in equity and to some specific form of property in a chattel or chose in action similarly recognized, but that it extends to innominate and anomalous interests and includes the assumption and indefinite continuance of exclusive possession and control for the purposes of the Commonwealth of any subject of property. Section 51 (xxxi) serves a double purpose. It provides the Commonwealth Parliament with a legislative power of acquiring property: at the same time as a condition upon the exercise of the power it provides the individual or the State, affected with a protection against governmental interferences with his proprietary rights without just recompense. In both aspects consistency with the principles upon which constitutional provisions are interpreted and applied demands that the paragraph should be given as full and flexible an operation as will cover the objects it was designed to effect. Moreover, when a constitution undertakes to forbid or restrain some legislative course, there can be no prohibition to which it is more proper to apply the principle embodied . . . In requiring just terms s. 51(xxxi) fetters the legislative power by forbidding laws with respect to acquisition on any terms that are not just.
In Trade Practices Commission v. Tooth and Co. Ltd, as reported in CLR 142 at page 403, Barwick, C.J., as he then was, said:

It has been decided, and in my respectful opinion quite correctly, that the presence of s. 51(xxxi) in the Constitution means that no other head of power, including the incidental power, would support a law for the acquisition of property.

In other words, this is the only head of power in the Constitution which allows the Commonwealth to acquire that property. The reason is plain. The constitutional purpose is to ensure that in no circumstance will a law of the Commonwealth provide for the acquisition of property except upon just terms.

para.tab: Section 51 is a very great constitutional safeguard not confined to the protection of the citizen from the confiscation of his property by the state. It ensures that no-one may by virtue of a Commonwealth statutory provision acquire his property except on just terms. Again, Gibbs picks up the question of a circuitous device saying that it simply will not be permitted to circumvent that clause of the Constitution.

On the question of the need for an acquisition to take place, as distinct from merely depriving someone of something, there is again relevant case law in the Tasmanian dams case. In the interests of time, I recommend people to the judgments of Justices Mason, Brennan and Deane, wherein they state very clearly that there has to be an acquisition of the property. Indeed, the important words of Brennan J, were:

speech.para: Where neither the Commonwealth nor any other person acquires property rights under a law of the Commonwealth, there is no acquisition upon which the paragraph may fasten.

But clearly in this case there is an acquisition of proprietary rights which are conferred upon third parties, as is encompassed in that statement of Brennan, J. The fact of the matter is that we have established that the time that is confiscated by the Government is property and there is an acquisition of it. We then come to the third point I raised at the beginning, and that is the question of whether it is acquired on just terms. Again, we can go to the case law, where it says that there is a simple definition of `just terms'. Mr Justice Starke in the Bank of New South Wales v. the Commonwealth said:
. . . "just terms" require that a party whose property is acquired shall have the pecuniary equivalent of the property acquired.

Quite clearly, this legislation does not provide for that. As I said at the beginning in speaking to the motion moved by Senator Parer, that the two of parts of the Bill should be separated and dealt with as two entirely separate pieces of legislation is not only reasonable but is logical, sensible and equitable. The Democrats have been placed in a position where they have had some legal advice and some advices made available to them—advices which I might say at this stage I have not seen but which I would be interested in looking at.

para.tab: This area is one in which a prima facie case has been made out that this legislation could indeed be ultra vires the Constitution. As such, any reasonable man, or indeed any reasonable Minister, would consider that it is a logical and sensible course of action to now deal with the question of disclosure but to leave the question of whether this legislation either is or can be made valid so that proper investigation can be made. In fairness to the people with whom the Government has offered a deal—the Democrats—and in their own interests, it would be sensible for them to look at what sort of deal it is that they have struck.

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak briefly to the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 as it now stands with the Government amendments, and the proposals by the Opposition to correct what we believe is an outrageous attack on freedom of political expression in this country.

para.tab: The Bill as it now stands with the Government amendments is such that during an election campaign all paid advertising on the electronic media—radio and television—will be banned. This applies to Federal, State and local government elections. It also means that at any time during the election period—which is defined from the close of nominations to the election date—no third party can pay for any advertisement on radio and television. We understand the position with regard to television, that it is a costly exercise; we are totally mystified as to why it should apply to radio.

Regarding so-called free advertising, there is no such thing as free advertising because someone has to pay. In respect of television, the television stations have to pay. According to the calculations made by my colleague Senator Kemp, supported by Senator Kernot of the Democrats, during an election period the cost to the three television stations covering the Sydney area alone would be of the order of $5m. If one extrapolates that out to the rest of Australia one sees the amount of money involved. One sees the amount of about $1.8m that would accrue to the Australian Democrats on so-called free advertisements paid for by the commercial television stations that, financially, have been in diabolical trouble.

The coalition seeks to amend some of the Government's amendments. I will touch on the key amendments briefly; I will not go through the more minor ones. One of them is to remove the Territories and States from the coverage of this legislation on the basis that the role of this Parliament is to cover Federal elections. It is up to the States and the Territories to then make their own decisions as to what they want to do with regard to advertising during election campaigns. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) talks a lot about federalism and cooperative federalism and this just shows how phoney his arguments are.

The Opposition also wishes to amend the Government's deal with the Australian Democrats to have so-called talking heads. It should be made clear to everyone that this legislation means that on television we can have visible to the public only the head and shoulders of the person who is speaking, and the ad must run for a minimum of two minutes. The aim, as has been said by many newspaper reporters, is to make it boring, boring, boring, so that people will not watch television.

I have heard Senator Coulter speak on this matter on a number of occasions and I think it is fascinating that the Australian Democrats introduced a talking heads proposal which they pinched from France. It is appropriate that it was the French who discovered the guillotine, and we have talking heads. Wonderful—a cartoonist's delight, I might say.

But this is the trade-off and we have sought to amend that, not in any extravagant fashion but simply by allowing the presenter, the existing member of parliament or a future one, a Prime Minister or a Leader of the Opposition, to have at his or her disposal static captions, charts and things that make sense. Without that, as various newspaper reports have said, the concept is absolutely idiotic. It is like going on television to sell a motor car without showing the car.

The Opposition is in the business of selling a product; of telling people why its product is better than the Government's product. We are also in a position to criticise, quite correctly where it is needed, the Government's actions over the past three years, eight years or whatever it might be. This is an attempt, and a very transparent attempt, to bring about television advertising which will be paid for not by the political parties but by the television stations themselves. That is abominable.

Radio advertisements during election campaigns will be totally banned and the Opposition seeks to amend the Bill to allow a political party or third party to advertise on radio during election campaigns. After all, when we look at audience coverage, radio advertising is the cheapest form of media advertising. It is much cheaper than newspapers and it is much cheaper than magazines, yet it is the Government's penchant—supported by the Australian Democrats—to block out any sort of advertising on radio during election campaigns.
We also seek to remove public funding for political parties. We believe it is most improper, and we have had that view since this Government introduced it in 1983 or 1984.

He knows that if the Government is taking bags full—and I might say big bags, not brown paper bags—of taxpayers' money without taxpayers having any say in it, then we are opposed to it.
—You are going to be in it, too.

—When we get ourselves into government at the next election, we will remove it. It is most improper. We also oppose the Government's proposal to increase public funding. The country is in an economic mess and the Government is suggesting that the public funding for Senate campaigns should go up to the level of the House of Representatives. This would increase public funding—the taxpayers' money going to political parties—by $5m a year. We will oppose that.

para.tab: In regard to disclosure, we have simply taken the view that we do not agree with the Government's amendment and we believe disclosure should be by legislation and not by regulation. Neither should the Government by regulation have the power to exempt individuals or groups in the community from having to put in a return in respect of disclosure.

We are requiring that Commonwealth government departments provide annual returns of income and expenditure for all amounts paid out for matters such as advertising agency services, market research, polling organisation services, direct mail and media advertising. This Government has made an art form of using its government departments to promote itself. We believe this should be put on the record once a year. We can ourselves, if we are somewhat astute, draw some of this information in Estimates committees. However, it is time consuming and we are never too sure that we have all of the information we seek.

Another thing we require is that where a person has to furnish a return and that person makes a false or misleading statement, he or she should be guilty of an offence and, on conviction, pay a fine not exceeding $5,000. We have also introduced a detailed clause in respect of discrimination which carries a penalty of $5,000 or two years imprisonment for a `natural person', and $20,000 for an offender which is a body corporate.

We would also like to see that the groups in society which get Commonwealth government funding be required to state on any advertisement, handbill, pamphlet or notice that they put out that they are in receipt of government funding, and also state the amount of that funding.

In an effort to get a level playing field, and bearing in mind that the vast majority of funding to the ALP comes from the trade union movement and is of a tax-free status—after all, the ALP is the political arm of the trade union movement—we believe, in conjunction with our proposal to remove public funding, that any contributions made to political parties, whether it be the Liberal Party, the National Party or the Democrats, should be tax deductible for donations over $2. That seems to us to be the only way that we can get some equity between the parties.

Another amendment we would seek to move would be that, instead of trade unions simply taking union dues and contributing moneys to the ALP without reference to the individual unionists, the individual within the union should be required to authorise a contribution to the ALP; that authorisation should be required on a yearly basis and any such contributions should be paid into a separate account maintained by the organisation of that branch.

I have tried to describe the situation as it is under the Bill with the Government's amendments and the amendments that we will move to try to restore the freedom of political expression and speech in this country and also to introduce equity and to introduce penalties for discrimination in respect of donations to political parties.

talk.start.para: —I allowed Senator Parer to range widely over the whole Bill, because he was leading for the Opposition, but I remind honourable senators that the question is that clause 1 stand as printed.

speech.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talker.name: Senator COLLINS
talker.role: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

talk.start.para: —Mr Chairman, I will, of course, be guided by you on this, but the reason I wish to speak briefly is to respond to some of the matters raised by Senator Parer and particularly his reference to excluding the States and Territories from the ambit of this legislation. I advise the Committee that this will be the only time during the whole committee stage debate that I intend to say anything at all.
—On the basis that Senator Parer's speech ranged widely, I think you should proceed.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I can assure the Committee that I will not be speaking again. I want to state very positively that I object strongly to Senator Parer's suggestion that the Territory should be removed from the ambit of this legislation.

para.tab: In speaking very briefly to this and, I think, providing some rather substantive reasons as to why this should not happen, I would also like to direct some remarks through you, Mr Chairman, to Senator Sowada. I listened very carefully to most speeches last night and particularly to Senator Sowada's contribution. I certainly acknowledge that she did create a very attractive ivory tower and, like Rapunzel, sat at the top of it and supported the opposition to this legislation. However, I do not think Senator Sowada appreciates on what a dreadful foundation that ivory tower rests. The material which this Bill seeks to remove just in those final few weeks of campaigning, in 99 per cent of the cases involved, no matter who produced it, is garbage, is offensive and adds nothing. It might be clever marketing and advertising, but it does not add anything to democracy and free speech.

I conclude by making my case. The last election campaign in the Northern Territory—this would be of interest to all people interested in political analysis and certainly the academics—was the most extraordinary ever run in Australia. I have never seen a campaign like it. The only campaigns I have seen similar to it have been the many television campaigns run in the United States. Some of those campaigns are beyond belief in terms of the negative campaigning for which the US has become famous.

talk.start.para: —Look at Goss; what did he do?

—It is still an unusual technique, I think Senator Parer will concede, in Australia. The last election campaign—the most extraordinary and negative campaign I have ever seen run—singled out the then Labor leader, Terry Smith, for special attention and absolutely crucified him. About a fortnight ago, Terry Smith resigned from the Parliament, I regret to say, and left the Northern Territory to live in Victoria. There is no getting away from the fact that, as tough as we all like to pretend we are, the extent to which he was personally attacked during that campaign struck deeply at both him and his family.

para.tab:
I was fascinated to see the smartypants advertising agency boasting—I commend this extraordinary article to the Committee—about how and why it did it, to the extent that it actually stated that it chose the day on which Northern Territorians went to the poll. It was not the Government of the Northern Territory or its Chief Minister but the advertising agency. It was a one-stop shop. It was just paid the big, fat cheque and it even chose the day. That is very democratic. The article from the Adelaide
Advertiser
—I am happy to table it so that honourable senators will know that I am quoting it accurately—says:
When an advertising agency commits itself to a political campaign moral issues or political biases don't enter the scheme of things.
The agency has to devote all its energies to winning the election and the irony is that political campaigns are geared to bribe the swing voters rather than shape solid election policies.

From a marketing perspective, the less decisive, the less interested, the less informed the voter, the more desirable, the more influential and the more seducible their vote, or so says Adelaide advertising agency Stokes King DDB Needham, fresh from a victory in the Northern Territory. Stokes spent October campaigning for the Northern Territory Country Liberal party.

"The Country Liberal Government was returned with an 11 per cent swing and an increased majority, the Greens were decimated, the Nationals failed to win a seat and will probably collapse as a consequence, and the Labor Leader, Terry Smith, will not recontest his position." Stokes. . . says.
But how was this formidable success achieved?
According to the beaten Mr Smith, Labor was defeated by the brilliantly executed negative scare tactics of the Stokes campaign—

speech.para: and we were. The article continues:

para.tab: The campaign was planned in mid-September when John King, Toby Ralph and federal secretariat staffer Graham Morris went to Darwin to recommend an election date and strategy.
After two days of intense debate, the group decided on an election date of October 27. . .

speech.para: As a Territorian, I was offended to find out that an ad agency had actually chosen the day on which I went to vote. The article continues:

para.tab: "The first part of our negative strategy was a vicious attack on the Labor leader, Terry Smith," Ralph says.
"We wanted to position him as a knocker.
"This would make it difficult for him to attack us and force him to run an ineffective positive campaign."
The second stage was designed to ambush any Labor initiatives by aligning them with the failures of the Labor in Western Australia, Tasmania and Victoria.
This included using the song, I Hear You Knocking but You Can't Come in, together with a voice-over slamming Mr Smith as a knocker.
"We called him Terrence—not Terry—because it sounds more contrived and effeminate and very un-Territorian,". . .

speech.para: That is true. Every politician up to and including the Chief Minister, who had called him `Terry' for 10 years, called him Terence during the campaign. It sounded ridiculous.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I shall report progress.
