question.block.title: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the Minister's reported refusal to retire to the back bench to enable the Prime Minister to rejuvenate his Cabinet. In refusing to go, is the Minister simply continuing his support for the campaign to put Paul Keating in the Lodge or is he more concerned that his valued portfolio might fall into the hands of one of the Government's distinguished failures, Brian Howe or John Kerin?

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —It surprises me that Senator Baume, this scarred veteran of 100 shadow ministries, should come in here and ask that question of me. Senator Baume is one of the most vastly experienced senators here. He is in and out like a fiddler's elbow, becoming shadow Minister after shadow Minister, and is still sitting there hopefully waiting for the day when somebody will sweep him into power. The problem is that there are other people on the back bench who have different ideas about his future, and I am very surprised that he asked this question.
—Some people have ideas about you too!

—Senator Parer is making his brilliant interjections again. Some of the suggestions which have been made about my retirement come out of the febrile mind of the correspondent of the Melbourne
Age
, Michelle Grattan, who has written a number of articles about this. When I was in hospital in 1990, Michelle Grattan wrote a number of articles which suggested that I was about to be posted to London as the High Commissioner, then to Rome as the Ambassador, and so on. At that time I wrote a letter to the Melbourne
Age
saying, `I have been in Canberra for a long time as a Minister and as an Opposition member'.
—Too long.

—Too long for you, Senator Parer, yes; too long for you, old son. I have been in Canberra for a long time. I made the point that although I have been here for 17 years, Michelle Grattan has been here for 20 years. I suggested in a letter to the Melbourne
Age
that perhaps it would be a good idea if, in addition to posting me to London or Rome, the
Age
posted her somewhere. I suggested Iceland, firstly, because it has summits there from time to time which she could report on and, secondly, because the
Age
needs better coverage of Iceland; it has always been weak on Iceland. The response to that in the columns of the
Age
was that a number of people wrote letters to the
Age
saying, `Yes, that's a good idea; send Michelle Grattan to Iceland, send Paul Keating to Iceland and a few other people in the Parliament should be sent wherever they particularly favoured'. That is what happened in the correspondence columns of the
Age
.

para.tab: Michelle has done this again quite recently. Those mini-skirted camp followers in the press gallery have accepted the line in her story. Some of them—too lazy to find out the facts themselves—have run the same sort of line.

In answer to Senator Baume's question, I am not refusing to go. I have not been asked to go. When I decide to go, I will go. It will not be influenced by Senator Baume or anybody else, or any journalist writing in the press gallery.

In Michelle Grattan's latest effort, which is rating the PM's XI, this suggestion was made again. I must say, if one lacks wit one should not try to develop it. In relation to the Opposition XI, this was said:
Many of the Opposition. . . are rather like the Indian team—we know little of who they are or of what they are capable.

answer.para: I can tell Senator Baume the answer to that question: the public will not know who they are because they are not capable of demonstrating to the public who or what they are.

question.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para:
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question of the Minister, who certainly is no Merv Hughes. Will the Minister be using his remarkable skills as a letter writer to write to the
Age
, and to the
Australian
in particular, to refute the
Australian
's report today as follows:

para.tab: But at least one senior member of Cabinet who would have to be moved to allow for an effective reshuffle is refusing to budge.
The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, has privately told colleagues he has no intention of moving to the back-bench.

question.para: Where does the Minister intend to move and when does he expect to start writing the letters to the editor?

talk.start.para: —The Glenn Milne article to which Senator Baume refers is, to say the least, inaccurate, because this is not a matter which I have discussed with my colleagues, other than one, and in that respect my public position is quite clear. Any journalist who cares to check the facts can do so. As I pointed out in answer to the earlier question, Senator Baume's public position is not quite clear at all.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to reports of recent proposals to encourage employers to hire unemployed people at below award rates of pay? Have any other proposals been made recently that industrial awards should be replaced by individual employment contracts? Can the Minister provide information to honourable senators about the effect these proposals would have on ordinary Australian workers?

—I am asked whether my attention has been drawn to reports of proposals to encourage employers to hire unemployed workers at below the award rates of pay. My attention has been drawn to a proposal called Austrain on page 216 of the Hewson consumption tax package. This is a proposal for people—

para.tab:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —It is a consumption tax package, although those opposite would like to hide, as much as possible, the fact that they would impose a 15 per cent consumption tax on Australian consumers.

para.tab: This proposal means that people unemployed for 12 months would be made to work for 80 per cent of the award rate. The title `Austrain' suggests that this is an on-the-job training program for the unemployed, but it is quite clear from the documentation that no training requirement resides with the employer. Therefore, it is not a training program; it is a cheap labour scheme and, because it abolishes Jobstart, it removes any possibility of there being a training operation. This is a straight out cheap labour scheme which forces people to work for exploitation level wages. My colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training called it `Austslave' rather than `Austrain', and he is dead right about that.

This scheme distorts the labour market in two ways. First of all, workers who are required to work at 80 per cent of the minimum award rate—that is, 20 per cent below the fair rate as decided by the Industrial Relations Commission—are required to work for 18 months at that rate and then go on to the 100 per cent rate. After 18 months it is easy to see that unscrupulous employers will, in fact, sack workers employed under this scheme.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. It seems that Ministers are very forgetful in that they forget your ruling which was made only a week ago—that when a question is asked of them, they are not entitled to comment on Liberal Party policy and National Party policy, they may only comment on their own policy and comment on other issues as they are relevant to their own portfolio. Today, with a gallery full of school children or young men and women who are learning something about the Parliament, it might be helpful if you instruct them accordingly.
—Order! There is no point of order. I have listened carefully to the question. It is clearly within the Minister's portfolio responsibility.

—The first point I make is that workers are employed on this scheme for 80 per cent of the award rate and, after 18 months, they move to 100 per cent of the award rate. Unscrupulous employers will sack workers at that point and go and get another batch of 80 per centers. That is what this scheme does.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You have said that you listened to the question and it was clearly within order. I ask you: to what extent is the Minister permitted to debate the coalition's policy or, in this instance, misrepresent the coalition's Fightback program? Is it not a fact that, under the Standing Orders, he is not permitted at all to debate that program? If so, I ask you to draw that order to his attention.

—I have ruled many times in the past that the Chair is not required to judge the accuracy or truthfulness of an answer to a question in the Senate. The Minister is not allowed to debate. I do not believe that at this stage he has got to that point.

—The second reason why this Government will not introduce this scheme is that workers who are currently employed on a 100 per cent award rate—the proper, lawful rate—would be dismissed and replaced with workers on an 80 per cent rate. What we have here is a scheme of recycling workers which is, in fact, driving down wages. What we have here is an industrial relations policy designed to cut real wages for ordinary workers.

para.tab: It is a deliberate and intended policy. There are no unintended consequences about this; this is an intended policy. If we look at the industrial relations policy of the Opposition, we see that it is aimed at removing award protection for Australian workers, removing the Industrial Relations Commission, removing unions from the scene and, of course, introducing a consumption tax which will hike prices by 15 per cent. That is the New Zealand road; that is the dog-eat-dog, law of the jungle road. This Government will not have any part of it.

talk.start.para: —I was going to ask whether Senator Richardson's scalping has had anything to do with the leadership battle! My question is addressed to Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Has the Government any plans to implement measures which will encourage high income earners to take out private medical insurance thereby assisting to relieve the current stresses on the public hospital system; if not, how does the Government propose to rectify the imbalance between low income earners and the rest of the community in access to medical care?

—The Government will certainly not be engaging in any process of offering some sort of inducement, incentive or penalty for those who do not take out private health insurance in order to fund the gap between the AMA schedule fee—arrived at by a cosy arrangement between the doctors union, the AMA, and the private health insurers—and the Medicare fee.

para.tab: At the moment honourable senators opposite are proposing, via the private health insurance system, to take hundreds of millions of dollars out of the pockets of the families of Australia and transfer them to the doctors. This will be done via the health insurance scheme which those opposite are proposing to introduce.

We certainly do not believe in increasing the health care bills of Australian families by allowing honourable senators opposite to levy on each family the Medicare levy of 1.25 per cent, which they will maintain in all instances. They also propose to create a situation where families will be required to take out gap insurance in order to enable doctors to levy that AMA schedule fee and to get it paid. It will become the benchmark that people will have to pay when they go to the doctor's surgery for their primary health care. We are not in favour of doing anything which would encourage that sort of private health insurance scheme.

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of a speech given by Dr Hewson recently in Wollongong on reforming Australia's industrial relations? Does Dr Hewson suggest that Australia's labour markets simply do not work and that there is no variation in wages between workers, companies or industries based on their performance? Can the Minister advise whether this claim is true? Does the Government intend acting on it?
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. To what extent is Senator Sherry able to ask the Minister to comment on the speech of another person, in this instance, the Leader of the Opposition?

—There is no point of order. There are ways to ask a question on the Leader of the Opposition's speech. I think Senator Sherry said, `Is the Government going to implement those proposals?'. That is clearly within the Minister's portfolio.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Sherry read that question. My hearing of what he read out was not what you said he read out. Could we check what he has written down by asking him to table it?
—Order! I have been reminded that Senator Sherry said, `Does the Government intend to act on this?', and I take that to be the same.

—I have seen a copy of Dr Hewson's speech. It was the Sir Richard Kirby memorial lecture at Wollongong University. It is a frightening irony that a speech such as this should be given in the name of such a distinguished former president of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission as Sir Richard. If one looks at the speech, one can see that Dr Hewson, a former professor of economics, does not understand, or does not appear to understand, the basic and fundamental concept of a minimum rates award.

para.tab: Minimum rates awards, of course, almost universally come from the Industrial Relations Commission. They are awards based on what the industry sector can afford to pay. They are couched so that the weakest employer in that industry sector can afford to pay those rates. They are, in effect, a true minimum. Employers can and do make over-award payments; where there are unionised workplaces there is often a formalised agreement. In non-union shops, over-award payments are often made by agreement between the individual worker and the employer. The concept of a minimum rates award is fundamental and basic to industrial relations in this country. What did Dr Hewson say about it? He said that differences in wages between individuals in the same company did not occur, differences between companies in the same industries did not occur, and differences between industries did not exist. He went on to say that firms in Broome, Geelong, Sydney, Melbourne or Townsville would have to pay a uniform amount regardless of their particular circumstances.

Quite clearly, Dr Hewson does not understand the concept of minimum rates awards and how employers, who have a financially stronger position and have greater productivity than the minimum employer performance in their industry sector or who are more profitable, in fact pay above the awards. As well, Dr Hewson is not speaking the truth when he says that there is uniformity in award rates.

I quote from a survey conducted in the metal trades industry in March 1989. It is a survey on the dispersion of incomes for process workers across the metal trades area. Across the metal trades industries in Australia, the weekly wage for process workers varied between $270 and $514 per week. So much for the uniformity between Broome and Geelong. The survey found that the weekly wage for a fitter varied between $344 and $711 a week. It has to be said that that is the finding of an objective survey. All of those occupations in this industry sector are covered by the same metal trades minimum rates award. There are clearly differences between individuals; there are clearly differences between companies; and the metal trades industry differs from other industry sectors.

What Opposition members have said, and one of the reasons why the Government will not follow this course, is that industrial relations is the key area of difference between us and them and the key issue in the so-called `Frightpack' that they have produced. In that document of over 500 pages there are only one and a bit pages devoted to industrial relations, so we remain somewhat in the dark about it. What we do know is that Dr Hewson is wrong on some very fundamental points.

talk.start.para: —Go on, dry up!

—I am answering a question from an honourable senator and I would have thought Senator Archer would conduct himself with some dignity. Dr Hewson is blundering around with a fanciful understanding. If this is the difference a computer-driven brain makes in the human field of industrial relations, pity help this country should the Opposition ever get into power and have an opportunity to impose the New Zealand model of scorched earth industrial relations on Australia.

—Could the Minister representing the Treasurer confirm that Italy and Portugal—and France will soon join them—have removed tobacco and alcohol from their consumer price indexes and tell the Senate which other countries have removed tobacco and alcohol from their CPIs? Could he confirm that before the Budget the Government received a combined submission from the Australian Council on Smoking and Health, the Anti-Cancer Council of Victoria, the Anti-Cancer Foundation of the South Australian universities, the New South Wales Cancer Council, the Cancer Foundation of Western Australia, the Non-Smokers Movement of Australia, Action on Smoking and Health and the National Heart Foundation calling for a massive increase in tobacco excise because of its price sensitivity and because tobacco is one of the biggest preventable causes of ill health and death in Australia? Could the Minister indicate the Government's response to that submission and give a commitment that the Government will introduce legislation to exclude tobacco and alcohol from the CPI?

—I am not in a position to say whether France, Italy and Portugal have removed tobacco and alcohol from their CPIs, but I do know enough about it to say that if France removed alcohol from the CPI, there would be a big fall in government revenue. Submissions which have been made to the Government by various bodies have not been made to me. They may have been made to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services or to the Treasurer, and I will seek, from the Treasurer initially, the Government's response to that question.

question.block.title: Sale of Patrol Boats to the Philippines

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence and concerns the Australian Submarine Corporation's proposed sale of three patrol boats to the Government of the Philippines. I ask the Minister what will be the value of this contract if it is agreed to by the Philippines Government, and whether it is true that the Philippines Government has made the contract conditional on a loan or grant of $140m to pay for the sale. Is the Minister aware of the recent statement by Professor Roland Simbulan, an aide to Philippines Senator Tanada, that the Philippines Navy uses patrol boats as part of its counterinsurgency operations, particularly in the Visayas and in Mindanao? If this is the case, is he prepared to block the application for an export licence?

—Approval in principle to export patrol boats to the Philippines was given in January 1990 and commercial negotiations have been under way since then to seal that contract. An application for an export permit will need to be submitted and a permit granted before the vessels can be exported from Australia. I understand that the value of the contract is about $215m. Of course, I am not responsible for the commercial arrangements made between the Australian Submarine Corporation and the Philippines Government.

para.tab: My colleague the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce announced in a press release on 19 November that the Government would approve a loan of $145m to the Philippines Navy. The loan will be provided through the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation. The basis of the decision was the benefit to Australian industry and it was subject to the condition that the loan would be used by the Philippines to build patrol boats at the Carrington shipyards and not on any preconditions imposed by the Philippines Government. I understand that the professor to whom Senator Vallentine referred has made a recent statement, but I am not fully apprised of the content of that statement.

The vessels are designed for use in coastal protection, anti-smuggling and national police duties in estuarine and coastal areas. I am advised that they are not suited for inland navigation and use in counter-insurgency operations in that context as they would be too large for such a role.

In relation to the question of whether I would block an application for export, I would have to consider, firstly, what the relevant standing interdepartmental committee would consider on this issue but on the surface, from my perusal of this particular scheme, I cannot at this stage see any reason why I would not approve the export licence.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. At the recent AIDEX exhibition the 1989 guidelines on export of defence and related goods were circulated to the exhibitors. I suggest that they are out-of-date and not as strict as the Minister, by his own admission, would like. Was this not misleading the defence contractors who need to know in advance what the rules are? I would be interested to know when the new guidelines will be available and when they will be enforced.

—I was not aware that the 1989 guidelines were handed out. I understand the revised ones, as discussed between Senator Evans and myself and announced in a couple of statements, are to be printed fairly soon. I think in that context that we would have circulated the 1989 guidelines just as a broad and general guide with some warning that amendments have been made. It might be a good way to get rid of the back stocks.
I would say to those who picked up the 1989 guidelines that they should apprise themselves of the various statements made by Senator Evans and me. When we reprint the copy—which, I noted, is coming very soon—they should pick up a new copy of the guidelines because they are, in some areas, quite substantially different from the 1989 guidelines.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Is the Minister aware of Australian Federal Police investigations into allegations that a Darwin lawyer, Mr Ken Parish, fraudulently concealed the mail of a policeman who was at that time engaged in civil litigation against the ABC whilst, incidentally, Mr Parish was engaged by the ABC to defend that action? If the Minister is aware of such allegations, will he advise the Senate what instructions, if any, he gave to the Federal Police on the timetable for the investigation, considering that Mr Parish is the Labor candidate for the by-election in the Northern Territory constituency of Millner, with the polling day to be next Saturday, 7 December?

—Quite clearly, Senator O'Chee has not been in the chamber on previous occasions when questions have been asked about particular AFP investigations. I will say quite definitely that I take no part whatsoever in issuing any direction to the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police or any of his officers as to any timetable which he or his officers might think appropriate to the investigation of an alleged offence against Commonwealth law. I think it is quite remarkable that Senator O'Chee should even assume that a Minister in a Federal government of either side of politics would take it upon himself to interfere in the investigation of a matter such as he has alleged. I have never undertaken such an interference and I certainly have not done so in this particular instance.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. If the Minister is aware of this investigation, is it true that the question of whether charges have been laid has been referred from Darwin to more senior and superior officers in the Australian Federal Police in Canberra?

—I have no wish to enter into Senator O'Chee's politics regarding a by-election to be held in the Northern Territory next weekend. I will take those further elements of the question on notice and if I think that there is any point in offering a reply I will do so.

Do recent developments in both indicators augur well for the future? Does the Minister accept that recent econometric modelling work indicates that foreign debt will show continued improvement relative to gross domestic product?

—This is an important matter, in connection with which I referred to recent developments in Question Time earlier this week. In a number of answers to questions from honourable senators I sought to present, dispassionately, data on these indicators and show how even in the most optimistic scenarios in the Opposition's so-called
Fightback!
document there will be a deterioration in the performance of the economy.

para.tab:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I must say that throughout this week there have been numerous very ineffective attempts to distract Ministers from giving answers, ranging from creating a great deal of noise to Senator Bishop showing a bit much knee earlier in the week. All these things have been used over the week to attempt to distract us from giving sensible answers to these questions.
—On a point of order—
—Senator, I gave you an acknowledgment at the time. I must say, as Industry Minister—
—Order! Senator Bishop on a point of order.

talk.start.para: —On a point of order, Mr President: the Minister was asked whether he would refer to certain statistics in relation to—

—
You're on the back foot, Robert.

—I do not think so at all. The question related to statistics concerning national debt. He is now seeking to debate the debate that in fact took place in the Senate yesterday afternoon. There is an appropriate time to do that. Under the Standing Orders he is not permitted to debate it now. I ask you again, Mr President, since you ask us to stick strictly to the rules, to ask him to stick strictly to the rules also and tell him he should not debate the subject.
—Order! I believe that the Leader of the Government has been in order, but he is not allowed to debate the issue.

—If I might just comment on the point of order, yesterday at Question Time honourable senators opposite would not listen to the answers because they did not want to hear them. After Question Time they got up and tried to debate them. That is the truth of the matter.

para.tab: I will come in a minute to whether the Government's forecasts are being delivered, but last week's foreign debt figure shows a stabilisation of Australia's foreign debt at about 35 per cent of GDP—not the 54 per cent which the Opposition is proudly talking about. Over the last three years the ratio of net foreign debt to GDP has been about 34 or 35 per cent and, over the last year, that has levelled out leading to a fall in the debt servicing burden of this country from 21 per cent of exports in 1990 to 19 per cent of exports in the September quarter 1991.

talk.start.para: —And it only cost a million unemployed.

—Senator Baume is revelling in unemployment because he thinks that will put his backside on this bench over here. He will not listen to these figures. The most appropriate way to keep Australia's foreign debt stabilised is to increase the export orientation of Australian industry and the Australian economy as a whole. The package which is offered as an alternative presents a very big threat to this task, with its expected boost to inflation and interest rates and its totally fallacious claims on productivity improvement. Under the high road scenario, as Senator Bishop said yesterday, that figure would be 54 per cent of GDP.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Button is now debating the issue. He is debating what he refers to as the Opposition's program. That is out of order. He is not entitled to do that under the Standing Orders, and I ask you to direct him to the Standing Orders.

para.tab: Under this Government the export orientation of this country has changed enormously. The performance of manufactured exporters in this country is the best in the OECD countries. We do not retreat from that, and the performance of the manufacturing sector in exports is something of which all Australians ought to be proud. In terms of our export orientation the worst thing would be for those sorts of inflation rates or interest rates to strike Australian industry. It would be the most debilitating thing possible in relation to turning around the expectations of this country in terms of economic growth.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I shall continue in the winning mode. Can the Minister further inform the Senate whether he expects that the foreign debt outlook will be influenced by the recently released trade data?

—In terms of the foreign debt outlook, let me say that we have a Budget forecast ratio of debt to GDP of 35 per cent. In so far as the recent performance of the Australian economy is concerned in respect of this issue, let me just give these figures. For three consecutive quarters—March, June and September—Australia has run a surplus on its balance of goods and services account.

—For this country a goods and services trade surplus simply means that all the goods and services which Australia now consumes, either from local production or imports, have been paid for without adding to foreign debt. That is what the supplementary question was about. We on this side will not be pushing for a debt to GDP ratio of 54 per cent by the end of the century. Honourable senators opposite ought to understand that this Government will not be going for that sort of target.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Does the Minister agree that when it comes to wages, strikes, inflation and economic growth Australia suffers from miscast perceptions and unfair stereotyping and do we in fact perform well? Does the Minister agree that strikes have declined by 70 per cent and that three-quarters of Australian firms have had no strikes at all? Does the Minister agree further that cooperation has overtaken confrontation and workplace reform and wage restraint are routine? Finally, does the Minister agree that inflation today is at a 20-year low?

—I agree, but I bet the Opposition does not agree with those propositions. I recognise in the question of Senator Giles words used in a speech given by Premier Nick Greiner in Tokyo just the other day. I am interested to see the reaction of the Opposition in rejecting the propositions that Premier Nick Greiner put forward. This is perhaps a split in the Liberal Party ranks. I am also pleased to see that even if it means he has to leave Australia to do it, Nick Greiner is prepared to say some true things about industrial relations perceptions in Australia. He is to be commended for that.

para.tab: The Opposition always tries to distort the record of industrial relations in this country, but what Nick Greiner has said is accurate in many respects. He said that `when it comes to wages, strikes, inflation and economic growth figures Australia suffers from miscast perceptions and unfair stereotyping'. He is referring of course to that period of the Hawke Government during which we have had moderate wage outcomes and a dramatic drop in strike levels and to the fact that we are now below the OECD countries in inflation levels. However, to some extent there is an unfair stereotyping and perception that those things have not been achieved.

Mr Greiner has said that strikes have declined by 70 per cent. Certainly it is true that the numbers of strikes have declined. If one compares the Fraser years with the Hawke years, it is ours over the Liberals by 61 per cent. I am not quite sure how Mr Greiner calculates 70 per cent. He may be choosing the high point of massive confrontation during the Fraser years and then declining from that level, picking up the reduction in strikes during the 1982-83 recession that the Opposition caused.

It is true that cooperation has overtaken confrontation in the Australian workplace and that we have engaged in award restructuring and workplace reform. Of course, the accord has been a fundamental tool in bringing Australians together in the field of industrial relations to work cooperatively and not in conflict, as has been the case in the past. It is also true that inflation is at a 20-year low.

I should also say that Australia would do better on all of these indicators if New South Wales lifted its game. It is true that the Greiner Government has dragged up the figures on strike levels when the rest of Australia has shown that it can perform better than New South Wales. To August 1991, the rate of industrial disputes in New South Wales was 50.7 per cent higher than the Australian average. If those opposite want to say that New South Wales is a manufacturing State, I point out that industrial disputes in Victoria were 23.9 per cent lower than the national average. In comparing Victoria and New South Wales, I emphasise that while Victoria was 23.9 per cent lower than the national average, New South Wales was 50.7 per cent higher.

Mr Greiner could help our national profile and overseas markets if he did something about his own backyard. When one looks at Mr Greiner's own backyard, one sees that in the New South Wales Government sector, in the rail area and the hospital and medical sectors, there have been disputes because the Government has mismanaged its public sector policy.
There was a massive dispute in New South Wales only recently when the Government brought in confrontationist industrial legislation. Perhaps I can offer some advice to Mr Greiner. He should get off the New Zealand road; he should copy the legislation that we have to improve industrial relations; and he should start trying to bring Australians together to work together in the workplace, rather than confronting them and involving himself in industrial conflict.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the turmoil in Premier Greiner's State, is the Government prepared to help him to improve industrial relations?

—I am prepared to help. In fact, there have been discussions between the New South Wales Government and the Commonwealth Government on pooling responsibilities for the industrial relations commissions in both States, and rationalising their procedures. Fundamentally, it requires a policy shift. One cannot have good industrial relations when one promotes conflict, bypasses the umpire and tries to scrap the award system. That is where Mr Greiner is wrong. If he followed the Government's model, he would get it right and dispute levels would decline even further.

—Senator Alston asked me a question; Senator Hill cannot take a cowardly point of order here. Senator Alston asked me a question about the launch of the Opposition's package and I am going to answer it without Senator Hill's interjections or cowardly points of order.

para.tab: The so-called launch of the Opposition's package has been accompanied by a lot of hype, but nowhere does the rhetoric match the facts or the modelling which is contained at page 342; nowhere does the rhetoric in the Senate match the facts which are set out in the document. As Senator Bishop and Senator Short said yesterday after Question Time, getting up with a collection of—

talk.start.para: —We'll deal with you after Question Time!

—I am shocked; I have been so nice to Senator Bishop today. I have gone out of my way, and she speaks to me like that. She says that she will deal with me after Question Time, after all my kindness to her today.

para.tab: There are a few things that emerge from the so-called launch of the Opposition's package. Firstly, there will be big tax cuts for the rich in Australia. If a person is on $75,000 a year, he will get $140—

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. —He did. There are a few things that are gradually emerging about the Opposition's tax package. The first thing I draw attention to is that if a person is on $75,000 a year and rich, he gets $140 to buy vegetables, shoes and shirts with the GST on them. If a person is on $30,000 a year, he gets $30 to do that. That is the sort of thing which the Opposition's tax package contains. Perhaps Gerry Hand did not have that in mind.

para.tab: Senator Bishop took a point of order and said that I am constrained to answer questions about Government policy and my portfolio. If that is the point of order she takes, it is not my business to comment on what Mr Gerry Hand said.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Are we finally to take it that by conceding Gerry Hand did not have a particular matter in mind, Gerry Hand got it wrong in his assessment? If Gerry Hand got it wrong, I ask whether Bob Carr got it wrong when he said that time was running out for the Federal Government to get cracking and fight the Opposition's plan for a GST; that it would lose this debate and eventually lose government.

—Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of an attempt being made at a high level in the United Nations to send an envoy to Jakarta to negotiate a UN fact finding mission to East Timor? Does the Minister believe that such a fact finding mission would investigate only the Santa Cruz cemetery massacre of 12 November, or would claims of subsequent executions and ongoing abuses be included? Has Australia, as reported in today's
Age
newspaper, recommended to the Indonesian authorities that they look favourably at such a UN fact finding mission? If so, what was the response?

—The Government has been keen almost from the outset to explore a role for the United Nations in response to the terrible events of 12 November. That has been made clear in a number of public statements made by me and the Prime Minister and in communications that have taken place between me and the Indonesian Ambassador here and also in Jakarta. Moreover, this is an issue that I will certainly be exploring and taking further during the course of my discussions in Indonesia in a couple of weeks time.

para.tab: Initially our view was that the most productive avenue for such a UN involvement might be for the head of the UN Centre for Human Rights, Mr Martenson, to visit Jakarta for discussions with the Indonesian authorities in the context of a seminar on human rights that was proposed to be held in Indonesia this month. That meeting has, for a variety of reasons, now been deferred, notwithstanding our representations and those of a number of others. We now understand that the United Nations Secretary-General has decided to send the UN Commission on Human Rights special rapporteur on summary or arbitrary executions, Mr Amos Wako, to visit Indonesia in pursuit of his mandate to investigate incidents of this kind. That is an existing mandate which is vested in him by the UN Commission on Human Rights, of which Indonesia is currently a member, and certainly that mandate, in our judgment, would extend to scrutiny of the events that occurred on 12 November.

The special rapporteur has not yet arrived in Jakarta. Although the Indonesian Government has been informed of the Secretary-General's decision, it does appear at this stage—at least as I was advised this morning—that it has not yet agreed to a specific role for the special rapporteur. Accordingly, a few hours ago I instructed the Australian Embassy in Jakarta to convey to the Indonesian authorities our view that they should receive and fully cooperate with the special rapporteur.

It is certainly our hope that the involvement of the special rapporteur, and perhaps UN involvement in other ways still to be explored, would enhance the international acceptability of the processes of investigation into the events of and the events surrounding 12 November. I make it clear in answer to the honourable senator's further question that the Australian Government does support all efforts to investigate not only the Santa Cruz killings themselves but also any associated allegations of abuse of human rights, including any allegations of subsequent executions.

I might say, a little more generally and finally, that we do believe that the UN can play a positive role not only in respect of this immediate investigation but also in developing an understanding of and a respect for international standards of human rights in Indonesia through existing human rights mechanisms, and the UN could seek to improve the humanitarian situation in East Timor and help with the longer term resolution and reconciliation of the East Timorese problem. I repeat that the Government, in a variety of ways and through a variety of channels, will continue to explore such options.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can the Minister guarantee that people with disabilities will not be worse off, either in terms of program access or quality of training, as a result of the omission of group focused services for people with disabilities for the 1992 Skillshare guidelines? Why has the Government chosen to ignore its own draft Skillshare disability strategy paper which advocates the provision of additional modular funding from 1992 onwards for Skillshare projects that meet set targets in terms of clients with disabilities? Does the fact that DEET continues to distribute this draft strategy paper, although its contents are not reflected in the 1992 Skillshare guidelines, indicate that the Government should get its own house in order instead of making spurious claims about the coalition's policy in relation to people with disabilities?

—I do not know that I can answer all of Senator Patterson's question, but I do have some information which I think goes a long way towards doing that. I am informed that the Skillshare program guidelines for 1992 extend the capacity of the Skillshare network to provide an increased rate and quality of services to people with disabilities. There has in fact been a conscious effort to involve all 367 Skillshare projects in the Government's policy commitment to people with disabilities, rather than simply having a handful of projects specialising in services to people with those disabilities.

para.tab: In this respect it is worth noting that the Government introduced funding in 1991 for 10 disability access and support units whose role is to assist Skillshare projects to increase the range and quality of their training provision for people with disabilities.

I am further informed that, while recognising the good work done over the years through specialist projects, unfortunately it is the view of the Minister that this has had the effect of marginalising the provision of employment services and skills training to a comparatively small number of people with disabilities. Specifically, the problem has been that the new program guidelines have clarified the responsibility of generic Skillshare projects and the roles and functions of disability access support units have clearly indicated that additional outreach funding is available to the Skillshare projects to assist people with disabilities.

The Government's view is that the current approach provides the greatest range of training opportunities to people with disabilities with the least possible dislocation of home life and social contact. It also provides the opportunity for a person with a disability to undertake training which will be related to employment opportunities in the area in which he or she lives.

The strategy is one of service provision and is consistent with the Government's overall social justice strategy and the principles and objectives as embodied in the Disability Services Act 1986. I am further informed that this extension of service provision to people with disabilities through all generic Skillshare projects represents a significant contribution to the disability reform package which was implemented on 12 November 1991.

In this area the Government is driven by a recognition that currently people with disabilities represent 13.6 per cent of unemployed people awaiting placement. That is of concern to us. The percentage of people with disabilities being serviced by Skillshare projects this financial year has already increased for this period. We envisage through this strategy that the Skillshare network will achieve a 13.6 per cent participation rate by the end of 1994.

The Minister further advises of his concern that ACROD and Disabled Peoples International feel that they were excluded from the development of the Skillshare disability strategy for the provision of services. Further, it is the Minister's understanding that the consultants engaged to develop the strategy liaised with ACROD and DPI. He says, in conclusion, that it is always the case that when strategies for public policies are developed in consultation with a number of interest groups, there will be conflicting views expressed and not all ideas will be able to be included in the final document. As I say, I may not have answered all Senator Patterson's questions, but to the extent that I have not, I will get further information for her.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Maguire this day relating to Australia's balance of trade figures and foreign debt.

talk.start.para: —You're at it again. Never lay a glove on it.

—Senator Button has not listened to many commentators if he thinks that. During Question Time, in response to a question from Senator Maguire, Senator Button ranged very widely over a series of statistics, from interest rates to foreign debt to living standards and the like. Most of those so-called facts that he gave in his answer were either wrong or, at the very best, misleading, and I wish to address my remarks to two or three of them.

para.tab: Firstly, I address interest rates. In that context, Senator Button referred to the Syntec report which was released yesterday and reported in today's press. It claims that under the coalition's Fightback proposals, in the short term, interest rates would rise very steeply before falling very considerably later in the decade.

So far as the Syntec allegation is concerned, Syntec has made much the same mistake as that made by the Government in its analysis of the package. The Syntec forecasters have predicted an after-GST increase in the CPI for 1994 of 9.5 per cent under the coalition's proposals. On that basis, they forecast that nominal interest rates would rise to 13 per cent during the next term of government, which will be the first term of a coalition government. Presumably, Syntec made that forecast by adding an assessment of the real interest rate to apply in that year to the inflation rate. That simplistic rule of thumb may work in some situations, but why would nominal interest rates rise because of the GST when the GST has only a one-off impact on inflation, and when that one-off increase will be fully accommodated by monetary policy settings and by income tax reductions—

talk.start.para: —A credit squeeze. You closed off fiscal policy. You worked that out already.

—Just let me finish. Senator Walsh can have his go. From reading his column yesterday, he does not even understand how the GST works. The one-off increase in inflation will be fully accommodated by monetary policy settings and by income tax reductions which preserve the after-tax rate of return to investors, with reduced income taxes of course more than compensating for the one-off price increases. That has been made clear in the coalition's proposals from day one. The fact that the coalition will compensate low to middle income earners for the introduction of the GST through the tax and expenditure systems is precisely the approach that was going to be taken in 1985 by the Government, but that option, option C, was aborted when Bill Kelty said that he would not have it. So Syntec seems to have overlooked that quite fundamental and simple point.

para.tab: There are other things that one can say and should say about the Syntec report. We have acknowledged that our policies will lead to a one-off inflation increase. The Syntec analysis seems to assume that that increase will be ongoing and will feed on into interest rates. But there are two main reasons why that analysis is wrong.

First of all, the coalition's industrial relations policy will reduce the power of trade union leadership by removing the legal monopoly of the trade unions. What union claiming to represent the interests of its constituency would argue for unnecessary wage increases at a time of high unemployment? Secondly, given the lower marginal rates of taxation, not to mention our savings tax incentive scheme, there is no reason at all for the after-tax return on savings to fall, even with a one-off inflation increase. Thus any additional potential upward pressure on interest rates from that source is ameliorated.

Moreover, in a recent article by Peter Stemp, the Murphy model was used to model the inflation effects of an indirect/direct tax mix switch. It was concluded that, provided there is a consensus that there will be no flow-on wage increases in addition to the tax expenditure measures, there would be no ongoing inflationary boost. Therefore, from our point of view, that conclusion could be interpreted as follows: when we are elected on the merits of our package there will be community consensus that the tax expenditure measures outlined do compensate low to middle income earners and that that compensation is fully adequate.

We will also be given a mandate to introduce our industrial relations policy which will reduce the power of the trade unions. Thus we will be able to ensure that that inflationary impact is one-off. If there is any suggestion that our approach to this will be any different from the Government's, let me remind the Senate of the views in 1985 of the former Treasurer, Mr Keating, who was at that time the most ardent advocate of the introduction of the GST. He was asked about the impact on inflation of the option C proposal that he was putting forward. On 12 June 1985 he addressed a dinner of the Australian Finance Conference and he said:

speech.para: Some contributors to the taxation debate have expressed concern that the Government's preferred approach could have adverse effects on both inflation and the level of economic activity. . . As the minister most directly responsible for the Government's campaign against inflation and unemployment, let me say that if I believed the proposed switch to a consumption tax would have such dire consequences, I would not have a bar of it.
Paul Keating went on to say that once the trade union movement agreed to discounting—and there is no earthly reason why the
trade union movement would not agree to discounting this time around, given the compensation and the tax cuts that are proposed to accompany the GST:
The one-off effect on price levels quickly washes out of the system.

He was saying that in the context of a set of proposals which the Government itself admitted would lift the CPI by 6 1/2 per cent. We are talking about a set of proposals which would lift the CPI by 4.4 per cent, would lift the non-farm GDP deflator by only 2.2 per cent and, for virtually every Australian, would mean much fuller compensation for the one-off price impact of that. So much for the Syntec article and so much for Senator Button's attempt to utilise that today.

para.tab: Senator Button repeated the spurious statement made by the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) in Sydney yesterday in a speech in which he claimed that it was a myth that living standards have fallen in recent years. He claimed:

speech.para: Since 1983 real household disposable income has risen by 24 per cent. Per capita it has risen by over 10 per cent.

I am not sure where he got those figures. This morning I had the Parliamentary Library take out some figures on this matter to test the Treasurer's figures. There are more figures to come because in the time available I have only been able to get certain figures. I did seek permission from Senator Evans and Senator McMullan to incorporate a graph which shows the movement in real disposable income of a married couple in which both people are working, the wife working part time and the husband working full time, on average weekly earnings, with two dependent children. This graph shows that since 1983 the real disposable income of such a couple has fallen by 3 per cent, and since 1986 their real disposable income has fallen by more than 5 per cent. I now seek leave to incorporate the graph.

para.tab: Leave granted.

—

talk.start.para: —Senator Button cannot get away with misleading the Senate in the way he does every day at Question Time, when he either totally refuses to answer questions or wheels in facts that are just plain wrong. The last matter I want to mention—and I know Senator Bishop and perhaps other honourable senators will mention other matters—is Senator Button's reference today to Australia's international competitiveness, as judged by our capacity to service our foreign debt. What Senator Button did today was typical of him: he told only half the story. The figures he related today were only for Australia's foreign debt. Australia's obligations to the rest of the world are not only debt but also equity investment.

para.tab: When we include equity investment and, therefore, our total net foreign liabilities—not just our debt but debt plus equity, and we must cover the two—that tells a very different story. There has been a continually progressive increase in our net foreign liabilities. That figure was $183.3 billion for the September quarter; just one year ago it was $170.1 billion.

So over the last 12 months to the September quarter there has been an increase of $12 billion, or roughly 8 per cent. The annual cost of servicing those foreign liabilities is running at more than $17 billion, as we have said on numerous occasions in recent days. That figure equals 28.5 per cent of our exports of goods and services.

So Senator Button has given us today a misleading impression of our international competitive position. He was really just aping what the Treasurer, Mr Kerin, said in his speech in Sydney yesterday when he used much lower figures, and it is a very cruel distortion, an absolutely misleading interpretation of the figures. He is trying to disguise the very serious, fundamentally deep-seated problems that this economy faces.

Indeed, the indictment that has to be made of Mr Kerin as Treasurer is that in recent days, and particularly with what will turn out to be an infamous speech in Sydney yesterday, he has been trying to delude the Australian people into thinking that we do not have serious problems in the Australian economy. Unless we wake up to the seriousness of this situation, unless we adopt the sorts of radical changes and proposals that have been put forward by Dr Hewson and the coalition in the Fightback proposals, we will never ever make a start on stabilising, let alone turning around and correcting, those conditions.

Therefore, we will continue to condemn more than a million and a half Australians, many of them young people, to a continuing life of unemployment and underemployment. The Government might want to pursue that path, but I can tell Senator Button, the Senate, the Government and the Australian people that that is certainly not the course that the coalition proposes to follow.

talk.start.para: —Senator Short assured us that the 5 per cent, or whatever the figure finally turns out to be, boost to inflation, which according to the Syntec assessment will take the inflation rate close to 10 per cent again, will be a one-off boost to inflation because `other policy settings' will ensure a return to present outcomes.

para.tab: In so doing, he confirmed that the Opposition plans a credit squeeze. What other policy settings can ensure that that is a one-off only? There are two: it can tighten fiscal policy or it can tighten monetary policy. The Opposition has already committed itself not to tighten fiscal policy. The Opposition says that all the benefits of the expenditure cuts which it plans but has not specified, all the extra revenue which its value added tax will raise, will be totally refunded to other taxpayers in the form of personal income tax cuts.

The Opposition has closed the door on tightening fiscal policy three years ahead of time. So there is only one thing left for the Opposition: another credit squeeze—a repetition of New Zealand. New Zealand had a one-off boost in inflation. How did it achieve that? By pushing unemployment up by 5 percentage points. Clearly, that is what the Opposition plans to do. It has closed off the fiscal policy and there is only one policy setting left: another credit squeeze.

The Opposition's fall back argument, of course, is that it will emasculate the trade unions—a la Thatcher, who emasculated the trade unions in the United Kingdom and pushed both unemployment and inflation up to 13 per cent. That even beat John Howard's 1982-83 record. In the UK, Thatcher, after emasculating the trade unions, managed to put both unemployment and inflation up to 13 per cent. Either the Opposition is lying when it gives people the assurance that all the benefits of its expenditure cuts and the extra revenue its value added tax raises will be entirely passed on in the form of lower personal income tax or it is planning to control the inflationary consequences of its value added tax with a credit squeeze and a 4 or 5 per cent increase in unemployment. There is no escape from that logic for Senator Short.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Jones this day relating to employment.

speech.para: It is no wonder that the Government is finding itself in an increasingly impossible position in trying to attack the coalition's Fightback program. No doubt that is one of the reasons why people such as the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Gerry Hand, and Bob Carr have thrown in the towel. They have conceded that they are simply not making progress.

para.tab: We could not have had a better example of the Government's inept response than the answer given by Senator Cook today on a question relating to Austrain. Austrain is a program that has been put forward in our Fightback program as a deliberate means of providing on the job training via training wages for those who have been out of the work force for considerable periods. Those people who have been unemployed for six months or more will be able to work for 90 per cent of the award minimum wage, but the payment will need to be brought up to the full award minimum within 12 months. If they have been out of the work force for 12 months or more, they will be able to be employed for 80 per cent of the award wage, but it will need to be brought up to the minimum award figure within 18 months.

I would have thought that this is a perfectly unexceptionable proposition and, indeed, it is one that commends itself to a large number of employers. Those who have been interviewed in the media as prospective participants have made it clear that they regard this as a very attractive way of getting a foot in the door, getting into the real work force, and not simply being kept amused on the sidelines by some of these mickey mouse training programs that are currently on offer.

What did Senator Cook do in response to this proposal? First, he said that people will be made to work. I would have thought that one could be sufficiently charitable to assume that Senator Cook has actually read our document. If he had and had looked at page 255, he would have read:

speech.para: For those who have received social security benefits for a minimum of six months, special provisions will be introduced to allow the long term unemployed to accept special `on-the-job' training wage rates . . .
It is quite clear that it is a voluntary, not a compulsory, program. That is the first major misstatement on the part of the Minister.

para.tab: Secondly, he argues that this is somehow a distortion of the wages market and that it will lead to unscrupulous employers simply sacking people, the so-called churning argument. Again, even Senator Cook, who prides himself—precious though he might be—on being in touch with what is in documentation relating to work force practices, should also have read page 255, which states:

speech.para: Special safeguards will apply to ensure that full-wage employees are not merely replaced by those persons eligible for AUSTRAIN.
The Local Employment Boards will co-ordinate, approve and monitor the placement of AUSTRAIN trainees.

In other words, it will simply not be possible for people to be displaced, to be thrown out of a job position and replaced by someone else who might be in the Austrain market and, as a result, unfairly discriminate against those who are performing satisfactorily.

para.tab: It is perfectly plain from reading the document that that is precisely the role of local employment boards: to ensure that there is no exploitation and to monitor and approve—if necessary, disapprove—of employers who seek to exploit workers who might be in that position. It is sheer hypocrisy for Senator Cook to come in here and to be asked a question that enables him to run such a dishonest campaign.

I will conclude by demonstrating the disgraceful nature of this answer by referring to a couple of the Government's current training programs: one is Jobstart, which is a wage subsidy program in which the Government makes up the difference, so in principle a discount is still being paid; the other is Jobskills, which is a new initiative announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the March economic statement, which commenced from 1 July 1991. Only some weeks ago Senator Cook told the Senate that the basic award wage in this country was around $300 a week. I think he even referred to child-care workers as being on the bottom of the pile. There was no suggestion on his part that a person could get a job for less than that.

The purpose of Jobskills is, in fact, to engage people for less than the minimum award wage. Participants will be paid a training wage of $280 a week during their involvement with Jobskills. One would have thought that we are simply offering another form of training wage with the great virtue that it does not involve any cost to government. Indeed, it is a subsidy borne in the short term by the employee, who is delighted to be given that opportunity. Who should have endorsed Jobskills? No less than the ACTU. I have shown Senator Evans a letter from Bill Mansfield, the Assistant Secretary of the ACTU, to the Secretary of DEET and seek leave to incorporate the letter in
Hansard.
Leave granted.

The letter read as follows
—

speech.para: The Secretary
DEET
Central Office
GPO Box 9880
CANBERRA 2600
Dear Sir
Attention: Mr R Holstead

The ACTU has given initial consideration to the labor market proposals regarding TASK and Job Skills. Discussions have been held with DEET officers regarding the proposed programs and their essential features have been clarified.

It will be necessary for the ACTU to consult with relevant affiliates regarding this matter and I expect to be able to do this at a meeting to be held at the ACTU on Tuesday, May 28 at 10.00 a.m. It would be advantageous if DEET officers could attend that meeting. Following the meeting it may be necessary to discuss points of detail in the TASK and Job Skills programs.
The ACTU supports the general intention of the TASK and Job Skills programs and will be encouraging affiliates to respond positively to the proposals which have been made.
I will keep you informed of the developments.
Yours faithfully
W Mansfield
Assistant Secretary
I emphasise the last paragraph of the letter:
The ACTU supports the general intention of the TASK and Job Skills programs and will be encouraging affiliates to respond positively to the proposals which have been made.

If there is one Minister who comes into this place and prides himself on being in bed with the ACTU, doing everything it wants him to do, it is Senator Cook. He has no shame in owning up to that position. I would have thought the least he could do is to come in and acknowledge that the ACTU itself supports training programs. I will just remind him what the ACTU's 1989 youth strategy says:

para.tab: Wages rates should reflect the nature of the work and skills required including experience rather than age.
Trainee rates should apply throughout the training period and lead to an award rate commensurate with skill level upon completion.

speech.para: In other words, precisely what we are proposing is endorsed by the ACTU and confirmed in writing but dishonestly denied by Senator Cook.

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para:
—by leave—I wish to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented. There was an article on the front page of the
Australian Financial Review
this morning suggesting that the Opposition was proposing to introduce a new tax on employers as a means of implementing its low-wage assistance scheme for the jobless; in other words, Austrain. It is probably of some significance that Senator Cook did not refer to this article. The article talks about the mooted tax being a convoluted device. In a number of areas the article continues to talk in terms of a tax device and it quotes a spokesman commenting on my behalf.

para.tab: The fact is that at no stage have I or the Opposition proposed any such tax. The concept of a tax is that it is something that raises revenue. Austrain, by its very nature, is not designed to raise revenue; indeed, it is designed to save revenue. We have already committed ourselves to abolishing seven taxes. The Government has followed suit with the coal levy, and presumably it will be doing its best to continue to follow suit in due course.

The last thing I have suggested in public is that we want to introduce new taxes. Indeed, Austrain goes in the opposite direction. Therefore, I simply want to make it clear that what is contained in that article is mere speculation about one possible alternative to initiatives that might involve the direct regulation of wages. But certainly the implementation of the Austrain program would not involve any new tax and would not, by definition, involve any new revenue raising. Indeed, quite the opposite: it will assist the Government and in particular the Minister for Finance by avoiding the need to provide social welfare benefits and other government transfer payments by having the burden borne in the private sector. I am grateful for the opportunity to set the record straight.

speech.speaker: Reid Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: In view of the need to get back to the business before us, which suffers the gag at 7.30 p.m., I shall be brief. I want to refer to the 1990-91 annual report of Film Australia Pty Ltd—of course the reporting period ends on 30 June 1991—because 1991 commemorates the eightieth year of Film Australia's operation, although it has not had that precise name from the time it began, on 15 November 1911. No doubt the eightieth birthday will be referred to in more detail in the next annual report, but that time is so far off that I felt it was better to refer to it today.

para.tab: Film Australia has celebrated its eightieth birthday in a number of ways. In particular, it celebrated in Canberra with a function at which it reviewed its history from its beginnings as James Pinkerton Campbell's one-man operation in 1911. It showed a film which highlighted the benefit of the work that it has done and the need for a country to record its history. Of course, the purpose of Film Australia is to record the development and building of the nation in that form.

At a function entitled `A Moving History of Australia: Film Australia 1911—1991', the following films were shown:
The Opening of Canberra
, a 1927 black and white silent film;
The National Capital
, a 1945 film showing Canberra at the end of the War; and
Canberra Today & Tomorrow
, a 1959 colour film. That film was absolutely fascinating. It showed some of the young men who were behind the building and growth of the national capital—Sir John Overall and Mr Bob Lansdowne come to mind as two who were seen in it as young men, and there were lots of others whom many of us recognised.

The film showed the growth of Canberra and the response of Canberra, even by 1959, to the decision of the Menzies Government that the nation should have a national capital of which it could be proud, and put everything into developing Canberra in the late 1950s, as we now see. The last segment was
Tomorrow's Canberra
, filmed in 1972, which gave us a vivid impression of Canberra at the beginning of the 1970s.
I hope there will be more such films of the national capital to show its history, and the many others referred to in the document which, while reviewing the last year and its success as a company, also gives some background to it.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak briefly to the annual report of Film Australia. I enjoyed attending the Sydney celebrations of its eightieth anniversary and I thank the directors of the organisation for inviting me to them.

para.tab: I am disappointed—this is one of my hobbyhorses, I guess—to see that the report is dated 8 October 1991 and it comes into this chamber two months later. Unless there is some very good excuse, it is not appropriate for that sort of time delay to take place.

I also note that the operating profit for the year—this is a corporatised organisation now—has fallen from $248,000 to just under $54,000. I would have thought that would have merited some comment in the text. It appears to have escaped the notice of the directors. It would have been appropriate to mention that—unless it has been, and I have not been able to find it in the time available to me. I think the quality of reporting could be increased.

The key question with respect to Film Australia is: having been corporatised, what should happen to it next? There is no doubt, in our view, that it should be privatised. Mr Gonski, the Chairman, states in the report:

speech.para: We now have the talent, the facilities, the structure and the balance sheet required to become a truly viable independent production house.

There appears to be no reason why Film Australia should not move towards privatisation except that, to an extent, it still depends heavily on specific programs such as the national interest program, which will involve a $18m contract from the Federal Government over the next three years. On the other hand, the report says that that contract now accounts for less than one-third of the company's total income. I hope that it can continue to expand its revenues in that way.

para.tab: There are a few other points relating to good reporting that concern me. For example, Film Australia has gone into a joint venture with a company called SoundFirm Pty Ltd, which is described as a Sydney based company—full stop. We know nothing more about that company, other than that, in the event of a wind-up, the property in the joint venture will be equally divided between Film Australia and SoundFirm. It would be nice to know what it actually put into this. Are the assets equally owned and what is the nature of the activities?
In other words, Film Australia is clearly moving in the right direction but there are some financial reporting aspects that it could certainly improve, particularly the timeliness of its report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

debate.sub1.title: Australian Film Finance Corporation Pty Ltd

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: The Australian Film Finance Corporation is the major instrument through which the Government's assistance to film is given. Unfortunately, this report, like Film Australia's report, seems to miss making the most important point that perhaps should be made—that is, what is going to happen to the level of grants to the Film Finance Corporation in the coming financial year? I understand that the grants structure under which it existed in the year to 30 June will not exist next year. It would have been nice for that point to have been made in the report.

para.tab: I mention in passing that the date of this report also provides me with some problems in relation to timing. The report from Mr Spigelman, the Chairman, to the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, Mr Simmons, is dated 11 September 1991, which is over two months ago. However, the Auditor-General's report is dated 18 October. I do not know how the report was transmitted from Film Australia to the Minister without the Auditor's report on it. Perhaps someone can explain that to me. I also noted that the Commonwealth grant fell from $74.8m to $66m in 1991. That does not appear to have been detailed in the report.

However, there are some very interesting matters in the report and I commend it to honourable senators. It points out some of the problems facing the Film Finance Corporation and the manner in which it has been successfully overcoming them, particularly with its successful prospectuses, which I hope I will have time to deal with.

It points out that sources of venture capital for such high risk speculative ventures as film are limited, conservative and becoming increasingly difficult and expensive to procure given the high level of guaranteed returns expected by financial intermediaries representing investors. The new onerous requirements of the corporations law in regard to offers to public fundraising is something we should have a look at. If these onerous new laws are making it difficult for proper and reasonable ventures to proceed, maybe there is a good case for examining whether we are throwing out the baby with the bath water, as the saying goes.

The report also deals with the present economic climate. However, the feature film fund raised $15m of the $19.9m budget and five films were selected by the Corporation for funding from 178 applications. The five films were
Deadly
and
Spotswood
, which were initially marketed; and
Garbo
,
The Last Days of Chez Nous
and
The Girl Who Came Late
, which will be marketed next year.

The Corporation noted a general improvement this year in the investment and recoupment structures of projects with, therefore, higher revenue potential to the Corporation for its investments. It said that the improvement can be attributed, in part, to the trend of the Corporation no longer subordinating its entitlement to returns in full to other investors, and also recouping the first dollar in as many territories as possible.
There are some other points I would like to make about this report, but in view of the time I simply seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

speech.speaker: Reid Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the document.

By contrast with Film Australia celebrating its eightieth birthday this year, the National Film and Sound Archive celebrates its sixth birthday. The report highlights the work that the Archive is doing to preserve nitrate film and other sound and visual treasures of this country which otherwise will be lost to us. The work that it has done over those six years and before it was formed has been outstanding.

para.tab: The report highlights the need for further resources to avoid losing some of the early material. I cannot stand up here and say that extra money should be given to it when we are in the midst of a recession. speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

It has been doing a number of things since then, particularly settling the plan of Canberra and identifying those portions of it which are the responsibility of the Commonwealth and within the national capital plan.

para.tab: The other thing that it has to do is work with the ACT Government and the ACT Planning Authority. Amongst works recommended for 1991-92 are Constitution Avenue extensions: design and construction. I stress that in my opinion the whole of Constitution Avenue needs to be designed and thought through and not just have bits done here and there and finish up either with a hotchpotch or with a decision that nobody could possibly change because this and that have been done and there are no other alternatives.

I believe that Constitution Avenue is important. One proposal came before the last inquiry of the Joint Committee on the ACT.
