The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)
—On behalf of the President and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the report of the Auditor-General, Audit Report No. 14 of 1991-92, Project Audits: Department of Employment, Education and Training—Abstudy, Assistance for Isolated Children, Protective Security.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: I will return to the Auditor-General's findings in respect of Abstudy in a minute because they are very serious. The findings relating to the assistance for isolated children do merit attention as well. The report states:

para.tab: Key findings of that audit were that:

speech.para:
.
mechanisms for program delivery needed to be simplified
.there had been little emphasis on the development of indicators to evaluate the effectiveness of the scheme
.there had been no comprehensive evaluation of the scheme in recent years, and
.there was a need for more rigorous adherence to departmental guidelines for establishing eligibility.
In relation to protective security the report states:

para.tab: Key findings were that the Department lacked a comprehensive national protective security policy and that it needed to:

speech.para: .undertake a Protective Security Risk Review to ensure it is aware of all information and assets which require protection—
it is rather curious that they do not seem to know what requires attention—
.institute appropriate organisational arrangements to provide for centralised co-ordination and control of protective security throughout the Department, and
.initiate an appropriate training program to ensure staff are aware of their responsibilities and obligations relating to protective security.
I now return to the question of Abstudy. There really are some problems in this area which the Government must do something about. The Auditor-General pointed out:

para.tab: The accepted Commonwealth definition of an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander is a person of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander descent who identifies as an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander, and is accepted as such by the community in which he or she lives, or has lived.

speech.para: It was noted, as in previous audits, that there was no verification check carried out, before payment, to determine whether an applicant satisfied this definition.

para.tab: The Department has previously maintained that various arrangements exist which act as safeguards. These include:

speech.para: .declaration on the application form concerning the student's aboriginality

.drawing the attention of applicants to the provisions of the
Crimes Act 1914
concerning misrepresentation, and
.a warning on the application form that evidence to support the declaration may be sought.

The ANAO acknowledged the administrative burden that a 100% verification check of Aboriginality would entail, but believes some use of verification checks is required.

The ANAO
recommended
that random checks be carried out to establish that applicants meet the accepted definition of Aboriginality.-

speech.para: the Department has now agreed that it will do that—

para.tab: Enrolment and attendance checks are a key control in ensuring eligibility for benefits under the Abstudy program.

The Departmental Abstudy Policy Manual provides for checks to be undertaken of students' enrolment, continuing attendance, and progress in their approved course. The ANAO could find no evidence that these checks were being undertaken. These checks are important for the Department to:

speech.para: .ensure assistance was provided only to those students who had continuing eligibility throughout the academic year
.monitor adequately the degree to which the program objectives were being achieved, and
.make adjustments to amounts payable as required for low attendance levels.
This matter was taken up quite some time ago—back in 1988—by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which expressed its concern:

. . . that the Department is placing undue emphasis on such post-payment checks, and that insufficient attention may have been paid to tightening departmental procedures in all areas of program administration. The Committee understands that departmental records indicate that one in every five students under ABSEC may have received overpayments, and about one in six students under Abstudy.

The Audit Office recommended that some sort of check be undertaken. It is extraordinary, given the kinds of problems that have been raised in the past, that apparently nothing much had been done about it. I go on:

para.tab: The audit revealed that the use of the DSS clearance forms had been less than satisfactory. Many instances were noted where an applicant had stated that he/she was in receipt of a pension/benefit from DSS but that the Department did not advise DSS via the clearance form. The ANAO was advised that no clearance forms were to be forwarded to DSS, and that the onus would be on the applicant to advise DSS that they were in receipt of Abstudy payments.

The Audit Office is concerned that there has been a move to place the onus on Abstudy recipients to inform DSS that they are in receipt of Abstudy benefits. The ANAO considers that departments have a responsibility to put controls in place to ensure, as far as possible, that beneficiaries do not receive benefits to which they may not be entitled. The Department's present approach does not appear to meet its responsibilities.

speech.para: These are very important matters. There is $83m involved in this project. It would seem to me that the Department's reluctance to proceed adequately to fix up these sorts of problems which have been recognised for some time is not satisfactory. The report continues:

para.tab: The ANAO found that, in addition to receipt of a pension/benefit from DSS, it was possible for an applicant to be eligible for income from other departments or government bodies such as the Department of Veterans' Affairs or the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). It was noted that there was no liaison between the Department and these funding bodies to confirm receipt of income or benefits, and to provide the Department with some assurance that payments were being made only to applicants who were entitled.

speech.para: It is a sorry story. I will not detail any more of it. At this stage, because of the pressure on time, I defer to my parliamentary colleague.

speech.speaker: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

talk.start.para: —I want to touch on the section of the Auditor-General's report relating to assistance for isolated children. I will not speak for more than a minute because I understand we have to get onto the legislation which is diabolically lying before us. I note that on 1 January 1989 the Government introduced an assets test. It is stated:

speech.para: The test applies to all AIC benefits except the $1,500 means-test free component of boarding and second home allowances.

In the recently released and very well received tax package of the Liberal Party we propose to introduce the means test free component of boarding and second home allowances from $1,500 to $2,400, and we have removed the assets test on the means test free component. As honourable senators will know, something like 3,500 families are affected by this decision, and the Liberal Party is very mindful of the fact that living in an isolated or remote area ought not be a bar to equal and adequate education opportunities.

para.tab: Under the present circumstances, with the $1,500 limit, it is just not possible for many families to send their children away and give them a proper education, yet at the same time there is absolutely no opportunity for them to be properly educated if they stay at home. This Government has continuously failed to acknowledge that geographic location ought not be a bar to proper and effective education.

talk.start.para: —In speaking to the motion which Senator Baume has moved, I wish to raise one very small but extremely important aspect of the Auditor-General's Report No. 14 and the issue of assistance for isolated children contained therein. The report refers on page 33 to requirements on parents to provide verification of dependent children by way of birth certificates, although the Department of Employment, Education and Training has indicated that its view is that misrepresentation of the number of dependent children in a family is a low risk area. I wonder whether putting isolated parents and families to the expense of getting birth certificates and so on is appropriate. In the last paragraph of the document there is an indication of some possibility of data matching. But, of course, that also runs into problems with privacy that we have run into in other areas.

para.tab: In May 1990, I raised in this Parliament the case of a person living in Port Arthur in Tasmania who appealed against the removal of family allowance when her child reached the age of 16 because she was receiving a boarding allowance for a student child under the assistance for isolated children scheme. I referred that case to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, and asked him whether he had noted that the Social Security Appeals Tribunal had said that, because of the technical interpretation of the then section 81 of the Social Security Act, the appellant's appeal could not be upheld but that her case was—and I am quoting the Appeals Tribunal—`a reasonable case', and that it seemed unreasonable that receipt of AIC `should disqualify receipt of family allowance'.

I seem to recall that I moved an amendment at that stage, in May 1990, to give effect, as it were, to the views of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. The Minister indicated to me, and to the whole of the Senate on that occasion, that he, too, regarded the case as reasonable and regarded my amendment to be also reasonable. But he appealed to the Senate and to me not to proceed because the matter would need to be looked at further by the Government. Indeed, subsequently, the Government brought down amending legislation which remedied the problem which had been raised in the first place by my constituent in Port Arthur. The Minister stated clearly that he thought that that person also had a very good case for back payment of family allowance. To give the Minister his due, he had written to the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) about the matter.

The Minister for Finance, on 14 August 1991, replied with a letter which, in short, overrode the information given to me by the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson—on which basis I had withdrawn my amndment. That amendment would have been supported there and then because there was support for it from all around the chamber, from the Opposition and the Democrats. But I withdrew it on the basis of that indication from Senator Richardson. I was sure that, given his position in the Cabinet, a payment would be made to this constituent.

This is an important matter and I hope that the Minister for Social Security will continue his efforts in this regard. I refer to a letter that I wrote to him on 7 October 1991 requesting that this be done. I raise this issue now under this heading, and I will continue to raise it in the hope that the Minister will be successful in obtaining approval for payment to this constituent who is entitled, in my view and I think in the Minister's view, to some recognition of the fact that it was her case that pointed out the problem which was subsequently rectified. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

The article in the Adelaide

talk.start.para: —I intend to speak briefly to clause 1, unlike the previous speaker. Clause 1 states:

speech.para:
This Act may be cited as the
Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Act 1991
.

talk.start.para: —Can I suggest to Senator Kernot that we could put this off until tomorrow. That would be quite reasonable.

—Mr Chairman, I understand that, but the will of the Senate is able to be undertaken, no matter what the situation is. I understand that Senator Kernot has problems. I called attention to the state of the chamber to enable Senator Kernot to get here. We did not want to go ahead without her.
—Thank you. Senator Olsen was with me at the time.

—Yes, but we were going ahead. We do not have to rely on Senator Olsen to enable us to go ahead. I understand that Senator Kernot has problems with the ABC and because of that she wants to have a chat to Senator Bolkus. Rather than putting that off and being able to go through the Bill in the correct and proper fashion, clause by clause, why does Senator Kernot not have a tete-a-tete now and put this Bill off until completion tomorrow? It seems to me a very reasonable request that we ask for an extension of time for the Democrats so that they can have discussions with Senator Bolkus and come to some amicable arrangement. As it is, we do not want our time to be taken up on our amendments while the Democrats and the Government are chatting.

—I have moved that amendments Nos 1 to 6 be considered together with clauses Nos 1 to 5. Having considered that, we would go on to clause 6, on which I anticipate there will be a lot of debate. During that debate I would have a chance to talk with the Australian Democrats. The process of the Senate will not be held up because of that. Secondly, in the spirit in which Senator Parer suggested we deal with amendments cognately to deal with issues rather than specific provisions to be amended, the first Democrat amendment falls within a batch of amendments from the Democrats which could all be considered together after we consider clause 6.

—In the interest of speed, and because we do have a gag on this debate, we should display some commonsense so that we can complete this Bill. The Opposition does not intend to support what we see as being the Democrats' amendment, and I am not sure that the Democrats intend to proceed with it either. But, if we go along that track, there will be occasions in the debate on this Bill on which our amendments will not be supported, and there will be occasions when, if there had not been a gag, we would have called a division. We will simply make the point, when we realise we cannot win the debate, that we want it recorded that if there had not been a gag we would have called a division and opposed it or supported it. In this instance, as we will not be supporting the amendment, and I presume the Government is not supporting it—
—Like the Opposition, the Government is not supporting the Democrats' amendments on the ABC.

—I would like to explain what the difficulty is. The ABC, historically and very correctly, has always been concerned with its independence. This legislation brings the ABC under the umbrella of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. The ABC would prefer to cooperate with the concept of roadblocking but, instead of having the ABC under the umbrella of the Tribunal along with the commercial television networks and the Special Broadcasting Service, it would prefer us to create three separate entities—the Tribunal, the Corporation and the Service.

para.tab: A few minutes ago the ABC advised me—and Senator Schacht too, I believe—that it is prepared to accept what was the obstacle in this process, the final arbiter's point, when somebody has to decide who gets the last 10 per cent of free time. It was felt to be totally inappropriate to have three separate arbiters, maybe tossing three separate coins. It was totally impractical for the ABC to be left out of that. The ABC—and I believe I am representing its concern for its integrity—is very happy to accept being a part of the Tribunal's final arbitration system on the matter of the last 10 per cent for minority parties. That is the only change I would need to make to the amendments in front of the Minister.

talk.start.para: —I think we are in the process of nitpicking—not on Senator Kernot's position, but the ABC's. If the ABC is prepared to accept the Tribunal to the extent that it indicates it is, it is not much further to accept what has been proposed by the Government. I could go into a long contribution about the ABC and its role in respect of the ABT, but I indicate at this stage that we will not be supporting the measure that has been flagged by Senator Kernot. If we do go into a longer debate, I will go into the reasons more extensively. By accepting some involvement by the ABT, it would not need much more to accept the involvement reflected in this Bill, of course on a without prejudice basis, in that we would not see this as a precedent for any future legislation in respect of the ABC.

—It is nice that Senator Kernot has been able to say that the ABC will accept certain things and not accept certain things. That seems a bit presumptuous to me. I simply make the point that this Bill obviously has not been thought through. All the dealing with and looking at has not yet been done. Senator Kernot is obviously off-foot—wrong-footed. She wants to do the right thing, but she does not have time to do it.
—I am not off-footed; I am waiting for an amendment.

—Why does Senator Kernot not agree with us now and tell the Government that we will lift the guillotine until some later day so that these important matters can be put together properly rather than on the run? Senator Kernot knows what happens when she does this sort of thing—she determines the Bill by talking to Senator Schacht and Senator Bolkus as she is on her feet trying to move amendments. It is ridiculous. Senator Kernot has to understand that this Bill is very complex and needs a lot more attention.
—The question before the Chair is that Government amendments Nos 1 to 6 be agreed to. Once that has been determined, the question will be that clauses 1 to 5, as amended or otherwise, be agreed to.

—I want to speak very briefly about the involvement of the ABT in regulating ABC free time. I have been spoken to by ABC representatives a couple of times in the last day. Their concern is that this is the foot in the door for a basic change, and that the ABT will become the regulatory body for program standards for the whole of the ABC. There will be a philosophical debate about that when the Government's major revamping of the broadcast Bill comes before the Parliament some time next year. We will debate it then.

para.tab: I indicated many months ago, as a member of the Caucus broadcasting subcommittee, that I am opposed to the ABC coming under the auspices of the ABT as far as programming is concerned. But I cannot see how this Bill can work effectively on allocation of free time with ABC and commercial television stations, particularly on the concept of blocking across the ABC station and the three commercial stations in capital cities, without having one body to decide who is going to have the 7.30 spot for two minutes or the 9.30 spot for two minutes. There must be one body doing it, and I think the best body is the ABT. But I want to put it on the record that I do not support that being the foot in the door for the ABC to come under the auspices of the ABT for general program standards and program content.

talk.start.para: —I do not have the amendment that Senator Kernot is talking about.

Clause 6.

talk.start.para: —There are some Government amendments to clause 6. Those amendments, broadly speaking, bring in a system of free time, and provide for the moratorium on political advertising from the date of announcement of the election to the date of polling. They bring in the framework for the allocation of free time and, as we have just acknowledged, bring in the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal as the forum, the mechanism, through which that free time provision is allocated.

para.tab: The amendments are quite extensive. They cover the allocation of free time to parties represented in this place and to candidates not represented in this place. As I say, that particular clause covers that framework. It also covers the question of political launches. There are a number of miscellaneous amendments to tie up changes that have been made to the Bill because of these consequential amendments. In essence, the Government is picking up the recommendations of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures which has just reported.

talk.start.para: —The majority recommendations.

—The majority of the recommendations of that Committee are picked up in our clause 6. The Opposition does have a number of amendments to clause 6. I do not know whether Senator Parer wants to handle all these together; it might be appropriate to do that. It may be appropriate to ask the Opposition how it wants to handle this.

—It would probably be best to invite Senator Parer to move the Opposition amendment No. 1 first, which provides that the part does not apply to radio broadcasts, and our following amendment applying to TV because they fundamentally affect what the Government is seeking to implement. If we are successful, that will change what follows. If we are not, then the Government's amendments which deal with matters of detail can be dealt with.

speech.speaker: Parer Sen W.R.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para:
1.
Clause 6, page 5, at end of proposed section 95, add the following subsection:

para.tab: "`(3) This Part does not apply to any radio broadcast.".

speech.para: Basically, the amendment removes a radio broadcast from the Bill, which would mean that anyone or any political party would be free at any time, 365 days of the year, irrespective of whether there is an election, to be able to place an advertisement with a radio station. Under the amendments proposed by the Government, advertisements during an election period would be banned on commercial radio and would only be permitted on the ABC within certain time frames.

talk.start.para: —Quite obviously, the Democrats will not support this. We support free time on commercial radio. It is a bit ironic that both the Government and the Opposition are supporting a total ban.
—We are not supporting a total ban.
—The Opposition is, by default, supporting a ban as a fall-back position on commercial radio.

—I speak briefly in support of my colleague Senator Parer. In many ways, I find the way the Government deals with radio to be the most astonishing part of this process that it is attempting to implement in law. The logic whereby one can have free time provided for television and not for radio simply escapes me. I simply cannot see why it would be supplied for one and not for the other.

para.tab: The second problem I have is that, if one accepts the argument, which I understand is promoted by some, that in some ways television advertising can be unreasonably emotive and unreasonably convincing and that is why one has to apply a special regime for television, then I do not think anyone argues that those same principles apply to radio. I have not heard anyone say that radio advertising in some ways is unfairly persuasive. If it is not unfairly persuasive, why are we concerned to prohibit advertising on radio?

The only argument to that would be that it is too expensive. But, as I understand it, radio advertising is actually quite moderately priced. It is certainly very moderately priced in relation to TV. There have been times in my life when I have been responsible for booking blocks of radio advertisements and, compared with booking blocks of TV advertisements, it costs almost nothing.

Not only is it moderately priced in relation to television, but also it is not particularly expensive in relation to print media which is allowed, of course, by this legislation. So it does not seem to me that the argument that is put against radio advertisements is that it is unfairly expensive, otherwise print media would be cut out as well.

The argument does not seem to be that it is unfairly emotive. So I cannot understand the argument to treat radio this way. That is why Senator Parer has moved this amendment. Our starting point is that the whole Bill is a fundamental breach of freedom of speech, but it seems to us particularly illogical in the way it deals with radio. We believe that the community should be entitled to take out radio advertisements and to pay for them during a period of elections. Therefore, we have moved to delete these provisions so that that fundamental right that has existed for Australians in the past will be able to continue.

talk.start.para: —I really cannot allow Senator Kernot to call it free time. It is not free time. If it is the ABC, the taxpayer is paying for it. If the taxpayer is not paying for it, the commercial radio stations are paying for it. It is not free time. It is typical of this Government that it refers to things being free for people—free health, free time for broadcasting. It is a misnomer and I plead with Senator Kernot not to fall for the trap. It is not free time. It might be free to the political parties but that is all.

—When we were considering this question on the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I recollect representations by the radio broadcasters which went to the points made by Senator Hill. They are valid points to consider. I will not say from time immemorial but certainly over years far beyond the years we have had television, people have been able to have their viewpoints expressed by paid advertisements over the broadcasting stations. It has been said by Senator Hill—I will not rehearse all the points made by him—that it is a relatively cheap way of getting a message across. It also ensures that the visually impaired are able to hear the message.
—It is covered elsewhere in the Bill.

—It is not covered for people who are affected perhaps by a policy that is contained in the policy launch when they are unable then to get their message across to the visually impaired. As far as that goes, they are unable to get it across to the hearing impaired if we are talking about television, except that they have the opportunity to read the advertisements placed by those persons or groups affected in the newspapers. But the visually impaired, of course, rely very substantially on the broadcasting stations. Might I also say that young people rely very substantially on radio broadcasts. Many of them do not read the daily papers; they listen to the radio.

para.tab: I urge the Government to consider the question that has just been raised. I think it is a fair question, even within the context of the problems that have been outlined, and I agree and am concerned about those problems of costs so far as television is concerned. But, even given that, this particular amendment fits in reasonably well and deserves consideration by the Committee.

talk.start.para: —Senator Harradine, who was a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters with me in a previous Parliament, must remember the evidence given by the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters. FARB made a couple of very interesting points. In principle it argued against any ban but, if there was to be a ban, it was absolutely opposed to free time on radio even more than television because of the very diverse nature of commercial radio and the awkwardness of fitting in with program arrangements. Once the Federation got past its objections to the principle of the ban as far as the workings of providing free time were concerned, from my recollection of the evidence it was totally opposed to free time. I think that is part of the response of the Government here today.

para.tab: I also want to point out that with radio we are dealing, as I say, with a much more diverse system of programs. Radio stations have specialised programming. We also have to deal with the major markets, and there are a couple of dozen commercial radio stations in the greater metropolitan Sydney or Melbourne markets. It is not as cheap as some people think for radio spot ads in the major markets. If we went to a top radio station in Sydney or Melbourne to place a 30-second advertisement, we would be paying $500, $600 or $700 each time.

talk.start.para: —For radio?
—For radio ads.
—For massive coverage; that is the point.

—For a very big coverage, true. But when one wants to buy a package of 30 or 40 ads on several of these stations at one time at $600 or $700 a pop, one suddenly runs up tens of thousands of dollars per day. The evidence before the Select Committee from the Broadcasting Tribunal showed that the increases in radio advertising costs were similar to those for television advertising. That certainly justifies the ban on paid advertising on radio being treated the same as television advertising.

—I want to make a few brief remarks on the contributions made by Senator Schacht and Senator Harradine. The Schacht report itself recognised that radio did play an important role. Senator Schacht and I may differ on the issue of free time and paid time in radio, but all the evidence before the Committee fully endorsed, I believe, the comments Senator Schacht made to the chamber that radio was a very important means of communication, particularly in election periods. Radio is important for people to be able to get messages across not only to the groups he mentioned but particularly to rural communities as well, which were excluded from the comments by Senator Schacht. I have to say that incomprehensibly and with no explanation the recommendation in the Schacht report to include radio was dropped out of the Bill. I am not sure why that was the case. Senator Schacht has not explained it to us; nor has the Minister.

para.tab: This debate will not end today—it will, of course, go on in the weeks and months to come—so I would like to ask Senator Coulter or Senator Kernot to put on record just why they are proposing to exclude radio. It is not clear to me why radio is being excluded, particularly in the light of the evidence produced before the Committee.

The final point I would like to make in relation to Senator Schacht's comments is that all the evidence before the Committee actually showed that of the four or five major forms of election campaigning—direct mail, TV advertising, radio advertising, telemarketing and so forth—the cheapest form was radio. If one wants to get a message to the widest number of people in the quickest time, radio is the way to go. So Senator Schacht is not correct in saying that radio is very expensive. In terms of the people reached, he would have to concede that radio is by far the cheapest form of electioneering.

On the logic of Senator Bolkus and Senator Schacht, and on this totally spurious argument of bought speech, we would have to exclude direct mail. Senator Harradine would not be able to run major direct mail campaigns and nor would Senator Kernot or Senator Coulter, because such campaigns are hugely expensive. So, on this famous logic of bought speech, if we want to buy that argument—and I do not wish to buy it—direct mail would certainly have to be banned.

I would like a very clear reason from Senator Coulter or Senator Kernot as to why radio is being totally excluded both in terms of free time, which is the Democrats policy, and in terms of paid ads, which is effectively the policy of the coalition.

talk.start.para: —I think I made the point very clearly this morning that time allocations in these persuasive media—and I would accept what Senator Hill said, that radio is not as persuasive as television; nonetheless it is a very persuasive medium—should be democratically determined and not determined by the ability to pay. Senator Kemp is quite wrong when he says we are not in favour of free time. In relation to radio Senator Kernot has in fact proposed an exactly parallel, analogous situation to that of television—that there would be a ban, plus the allocation of free time in the proportion that it would be with television on commercial stations, and for that very good reason.

talker.name: Senator BOSWELL
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: —I would like to direct a question to the Minister because I am becoming a little confused. I understand that the Democrats will move an amendment indicating that they will support allocating free time—Senator Coulter and Senator Kernot have just made that statement—on radio in a similar way to the way that they would allocate free time on television.
—Expropriate.

—Appropriate free time on television, although the term `free' has to be questioned.
The figure of about $18m was mentioned last night relating to television. Could the Minister give an indication of how much the figure for radio would be? How will that be allocated to the States? Will another $18m go to the States for every election or will a sum of money be allocated to, say, the New South Wales State election with a similar proportion of 40 per cent to the Government, 40 per cent to the Opposition, 10 per cent to the Australian Democrats and 10 per cent to the Independents? What happens in States where the Democrats are not represented in the Parliament? I would appreciate it if the Minister could enlighten me on those points because I think we need clarification before the debate can go further.

—The point I would make about the cost for free time for radio is that we have not seen the proposal. I anticipate that were one put before us, it would be within the same framework as the free time provisions for television. That would mean that under the theoretical proposal the broadcasters would have the capacity to extend their broadcasting of commercials time to accommodate any time allocated towards the advertising of political advertisements. To that extent it should be a balanced figure in that broadcasters would be able to broadcast political advertisements but would be able to make up that time by being allowed to advertise for the same amount of time in the normal commercial way.

para.tab: I think it is probably best for Senator Kernot to answer that question. I presume that her proposal would be similar to that for television. If that is the case, I contend that the answer is a nil cost at the end of the day. I defer to Senator Kernot because it is her proposal.

talker.name: Senator BOSWELL
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: —The Minister virtually said, `Don't worry about radio because we haven't got any propositions before us'. If that is the case, could the Minister enlighten me on how the money that relates to television would be allocated for State and local government election campaigns?

—I do not know whether it is any use my answering Senator Boswell. I have just given an answer in respect of radio, which was nothing like his interpretation of it. That minimum amount of time is, in respect of Federal elections, three two-minute broadcasts per day; for a State election two; and for a Territory as prescribed. I think that is the question that Senator Boswell asked me. Does Senator Boswell want me to indicate how that will translate to radio?
—I want to know the figure for television as it relates to the States.
—Two two-minute broadcasts is the minimum that would be required per day.
—Per station?
—That is right.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Is there an amendment by the Democrats to this? If there is, do we know what it is?
—No, there is no amendment. I made the point about free time on radio. It is not supported by either the Government or the Opposition, and I won't be proceeding.

—I understand that neither the Government nor the Democrats will support this amendment. As I mentioned earlier, in order to save time because of the gag on this Bill which was imposed by both the Government and the Australian Democrats, we will not be calling a division. I wish it to be recorded in
Hansard
that under normal circumstances we would have called a division supporting this amendment.

(b)the advertisement does not explicitly advocate voting for or against a candidate in an election or a political party.

speech.para: At the start of this process I went through Government amendments Nos 7 to 29 and explained the overall structure. I do not know that it would serve the Committee if I were to repeat what I said at the start.

talk.start.para: —In relation to the Minister's definition of a charitable organisation being an organisation whose objects are to benefit the public through the relief of poverty, I ask what he means by that. How would that be interpreted? Does it mean that the organisation would list its objects and that it would tell the Government that they are its objects? Or is it a subjective test? Do they really have to be the objects? How would one go about determining just what those objects are? Has the Government received any decent legal advice on just how that clause would be interpreted?

—The definition of `charitable organisation', like any other definition in the Act, as Senator Macdonald would know, is one for interpretation by the courts. In that process the courts would, of course, look at both the memorandum and incorporation documents of any such organisation and would also look at the operation of that organisation. We have had legal advice to indicate that the definition is sustainable. If Senator Macdonald were to look at definitions of charitable organisations as they have been defined, he would see that the courts have had a long history of defining what may or may not be a charitable organisation. I am sure that body of law would be quite relevant to any current court interpretation of the term.

—I would just ask the Australian Democrats to direct their minds to that question because it does open the way for bogus organisations, for particular groups, to have some objects like that and some objects that are not. As I said early this morning, it will be a field day for the lawyers. I ask the Democrats to consider whether they would not have some hesitation in supporting this amendment while that definition remains.

—I ask the Minister how he intends to close off the rort that could obviously take place when a holder of a public radio licence who provides a service to visually handicapped people is completely exempt from this in that any material can be broadcast that he or she is permitted to broadcast under section 119A.

—The provision that I think Senator Walters refers to is proposed section 95A(2), which talks about the holders of public radio licences. Basically, we are talking about those who do hold a licence and run a program for the visually handicapped. That is a specialised service. It is a distinct and discrete service from any other radio function. There would not be any loophole, escape clause or whatever. We are talking about a specific service targeted at the visually handicapped, and people hold licences for that.

—But, of course, there would be no control over people who run the radio stations. This is exactly the loophole I am asking the Minister to face. The radio station for visually handicapped people could make a point of having all political broadcasting done ad nauseam on this station. Because they are exempt, will they be able to accept paid advertising?

—I would like to comment on the point Senator Walters has raised because it was dealt with at some length in the hearings of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures. We had excellent evidence from the print handicapped people and, as a result of that evidence, the Select Committee made a major recommendation which the Government has accepted. We are talking about special radio stations.
—I am well aware of that.

—I understand the point Senator Walters is making is that a person, such as myself or herself, who is not print handicapped, could listen to the program. That is allowed, but the programming style, explained to us by the witnesses who run these programs, is done in a very balanced way. It is already operating that way. The station management and the organising committee at the station go to great lengths to ensure that the material which is read out from newspapers and magazines over the radio is balanced. There have been no complaints in the past about imbalance. I imagine that they will continue successfully with that programming in the future. If Senator Walters or I happen to listen to that station, I am sure we will listen to a balanced presentation—a reading of what may be the contents of the newspapers that day, including various advertisements. It will be done in a way that is balanced between all the political parties, as it has been operating in recent elections.

speech.speaker: Coulter Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —In answer to Senator Macdonald's question, in a similar way to what Senator Schacht has said in relation to proposed section 95A(2), proposed section 95A(3), where a broadcaster is broadcasting an advertisement for, or on behalf of, a charitable organisation, is qualified by two quite significant qualifiers:

speech.para: (a)the advertisement is aimed at promoting the objects of the organisation—
and clearly the organisation is defined as a charitable organisation—
(b)the advertisement does not explicitly advocate voting for or against a candidate in an election or a political party.
It does not seem to me to create a loophole, as suggested by Senator Macdonald.

talk.start.para: —How do you define the objects?
—These organisations will have to lodge a statement of objects. As usually happens, the objects of these organisations will be public documents. I see nothing creating a problem with that at all.

speech.speaker: Campbell Sen I.G.

talk.start.para: —The definition of `public health matter' is stated to be:

speech.para: . . . any matter relating to public health, other than matter that:

(a)
directly or indirectly promotes or criticises a particular public health system. . .

In Western Australia, on the rare occasions I have watched TV in the last few days, I have seen an advertisement by the Health Benefits Fund of Western Australia that specifically talks about the things for which Medicare does not cover people. This is obviously aimed at encouraging people to take out insurance to cover those sorts of things. Under this definition, would that type of advertisement be seen as a criticism of the public health system and therefore be banned?

speech.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talk.start.para: —There are two questions that need to be answered. The first one was asked by Senator Walters. Without repeating Senator Schacht's remarks, I mention the Senate Select Committee, but I also refer Senator Walters to the Broadcasting Act, particularly subsections 119AB (1) and (2). It is worth reading those out in respect of the licences that we are talking about for the visually handicapped. Subsection (1) provides:

speech.para: It is a condition of a public licence that the service provided pursuant to the licence is in accordance with the purpose for which the licence is granted.
Subsection (2) is interesting. It reads:
Subject to this section, the holder of a public radio licence shall not broadcast advertisements.

There is already a fair degree of control exercised over these licences. As Senator Schacht quite rightly said, the particular service that is provided for the visually handicapped is essentially the reading of newspapers, editorials and the like. We do not anticipate it presenting a problem. That provision is one that has been very solidly sought by the National Federation of Blind Citizens of Australia.

para.tab: Senator Campbell asked a question about the definition of `public health matter'. The only answer I can give is in line with the answer I gave Senator Macdonald earlier on. Any interpretation of the Bill and definitions within it must, of course, finally go to the court system. The provision itself is very clear. The intention is to allow the promotion of public health matters, whether they be the eradication of diseases or other similar health problems that prevail in society, without canvassing a political health issue related to a particular health system. I do put in the word `political' in relation to the canvassing of a particular health system and, to that extent, a court would make an interpretation on whether the advertisement that Senator Campbell mentioned came within that definition. It is very hard for me from here to know what he has been watching on television from Western Australia, particularly if the honourable senator has been over here the last few days and the advertisement has been playing in Western Australia during that period. However, the intention is to allow the canvassing of public health issues but, at the same time, have some control over political issues which may come within that broad parameter.

talk.start.para: —Perhaps I could be a little more specific. When this legislation comes into effect, we will be looking at a real world situation where the Health Benefits Fund runs an advertisement—I am sure there are similar advertisements around Australia—which says, `Medicare will not cover dental work, physiotherapy or occupational therapy. You should take out HBF'. I ask the Minister: will that sort of advertisement be banned under this legislation because it says that Medicare is no good because it does not do this? The advertisement is obviously not specifically political, but someone who is afraid of Medicare being criticised, such as the Minister, could interpret it that way, as could the Electoral Commission.

para.tab: Would an injunction be sought by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal or the Electoral Commission to stop that advertisement going to air? If an election were called in four weeks time, would that advertisement be stopped by way of injunction? What sort of certainty can we give these private sector companies which, in good faith, put a lot of money into preparing these advertisements? In a roundabout way, the advertisements specifically criticise the public health system by saying, `The public health system does not give you this, but the private sector can. Take out some insurance with the private sector'. I think the Minister is duty bound to inform the Committee and the people of Australia what this clause means. Otherwise, as Senator Macdonald says, it will be a lawyers' paradise. If the Minister cannot inform the Senate what this specifically means, how is the rest of Australia meant to know?

talk.start.para: —I think it is fair to say that the rest of Australia has known how to interpret the legislation in this respect for some 40 years. Over that period there has been a category of advertisements which have had to be tagged with respect to elections. That tagging has meant that, in a generic sense, political advertisements have had to have authorisation.

para.tab: This Act very clearly—Senator Campbell should understand this; he has been here all night on it—places a moratorium on political advertisements. This particular provision makes an exemption for the promotion of specific health matters. I have not seen the advertisement to which Senator Campbell refers. Clearly, political advertisements during an election campaign are not allowed to go on. If an organisation, for instance, runs a campaign for a better diet, a campaign against AIDS or a whole range of other areas that go to the issue of public health, that is not political.

I will go back to the point on which I started. For 40 years in this country, and for quite a long time internationally, the courts and communities have had to grapple with, and had operating in their systems, definitions of political matters. I will defer to Senator Schacht, who also has some knowledge in this area, and my advisers.

talk.start.para: —Ha, ha!

—It might be a bit difficult deferring to Senator Schacht sometimes, but he is an expert in this respect. There has not been one case which has been decided by a higher tribunal in this country. That is evidence of the fact that there have not been all that many problems in the community in applying the definition of `political advertisement', despite the heat that has been generated in recent months.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —I have two brief preliminary questions with respect to this matter. First, the amendment states:

speech.para: Nothing in this Part prevents a broadcaster from broadcasting public health matters, whether by way of advertisement or otherwise.

Does that mean that it cannot be broadcast over television or radio? Why have exemptions been given in respect of a matter of public health? Why have exemptions not been given in other areas of great national interest?

talk.start.para: —There are a number of representations, not the least of which came from Commissioner Burdekin from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, who advised government that we have some commitment in this area. At the same time, it was recognised by the Government as a policy issue that there should be a continuation of advertising with respect to issues that go to public health. As I mentioned earlier, they go to the fabric of public health, community health and an individual's health. One can draw a line between public health matters that go to the aspects that I mentioned and political health matters.

para.tab: The Government felt that it would be unfair, as a policy decision, to exclude public health from the ban. There is nothing more sinister than that about it; it is very much driven by a recognition of the social good that campaigns on public health issues produce.

talk.start.para: —I find the response of the Minister somewhat unsatisfactory. If we are concerned about the public health of Australian citizens, should we also not be concerned about the health of people in Papua New Guinea, East Timor and Africa, for example? If that is the case, why does the Government not exempt organisations whose area of concern is to support programs for the alleviation of disease and poverty internationally? That would seem to me to be logical. If the Government is exempting the area of public health, those organisations should also be exempted—perhaps they are already exempt. `Public health' is not defined specifically as the public health of Australians. Does this relate to public health only in Australia or does it relate to public health in Papua New Guinea as well? Where does it start and where does it end?

para.tab: Senator Bolkus indicated that Commissioner Brian Burdekin had commented on this issue. I thought that his main concern related to the alleviation of poverty. That is contained in the exemptions for charitable organisations. I insist on knowing what the Government has in mind with respect to exemptions for public health matters. I ask this against a background of a particularly hot debate in Tasmania at present—I have not caught up with what has happened in the last day. The Legislative Council in Tasmania is very much opposed to proposals by the Tasmanian Government in a Bill relating to public health and AIDS.

That Bill concerns an area of homosexual law and education in schools. I understand that the Legislative Council is standing firmly against certain proposals relating to education in schools. It fears, no doubt, that if certain provisions go into the law there will be nothing to prevent organisations which have a vested interest teaching kids that a homosexual lifestyle is equally valid as marriage.
That is where the Legislative Council has been taking a stand. It should be congratulated for that. I am sure that almost every parent in Tasmania would congratulate it for this stand.

When members of the Legislative Council are up for election, is the Minister suggesting that they cannot place advertisements? Is the Minister suggesting that the AIDS councils, some of whose members are very much protagonists in homosexual lobby groups, can place advertisements, yet individual legislative councillors, whom everybody knows but who may not be named, cannot place an advertisement contradicting what these organisations might say about a so-called public health matter?

talk.start.para: —There are probably two points to make. In respect of Senator Harradine's first point, the definition of `charitable organisation' probably picks up most of the organisations to which he refers. In respect of the second point, as I said in response to Senator Campbell, the canvassing of a politically coloured health issue is one matter and the canvassing of a public health issue is another.

para.tab: It is up to the courts to interpret but I refer Senator Harradine to subsection (b) of the definition of a public health matter, which makes it clear that advertisements which would advocate voting for or against a candidate or a political party in an election would not fall within the exemption. In that respect, one would make a determination of the particular advertisements. If a particular candidate, for instance, was tied very strongly, or seen to be tied, to a particular issue, it would be very much up to the court to make an assessment as to whether the link was strong enough to ensure that the exemption would not prevail.

speech.speaker: Parer Sen W.R.

talk.start.para: —by leave—(5.24 p.m.)—I move:

4.Government Amendment No. 10, proposed clause 6, paragraph 95A(3)(b), omit "explicitly".

"charitable organisation"

"exempt organisation"
means:
(a)a public organisation whose objects are to benefit the public through the relief of poverty, or the advancement of education, religion, public health or science; or

speech.para: I wish to touch briefly on these amendments. Amendment No. 5 seeks to change the name `charitable organisation' and replace it with the broad definition of `exempt organisation'.

para.tab: It is of some interest and some importance to note that amendment No. 4 seeks to remove the word `explicitly' from paragraph 95A(3)(b). It seemed that the word `explicitly' softened the intent. The Government's amendment says:

Nothing in this Part prevents a broadcaster from broadcasting . . . on behalf of, a charitable organisation if . . . the advertisement does not explicitly advocate voting for or against a candidate in an election . . .

speech.para: We believe it should read `the advertisement does not advocate'. The word `explicitly' is a bit too definitive.

talk.start.para: —I want to support the amendment to change `charitable organisation' to `exempt organisation'. One of the fundamental problems with this Bill and the use of the words `charitable organisation' is that the definition is restricted to those organisations where there is a benefit to the public through relief of poverty, advancement of education, religion, public health and science. It is a value judgment that only these sorts of organisations should be exempt. There are many other organisations in our society which should also be exempt from this—professional organisations, industry organisations, chambers of commerce and public interest groups.

para.tab: Broadly speaking, private sector organisations and enterprises may not seek to relieve poverty through charity but seek to create public good through enterprise, development and the creation of jobs. From time to time they bring important public issues before the public. Many of those public issues need not be political by nature. I would ask the Democrats to consider seriously whether or not applying a political ban to these sorts of organisations is something that they could even contemplate in a modern Western democracy. I plead with them to consider very carefully allowing these organisations to come into this exempt category so that they can advocate the advancement of their causes—be it an industry, professions or chambers of commerce—without clearly putting forward a political message. I seek the support of the Democrats and the Government for what I think is a sensible amendment to this legislation.

talk.start.para: —We cannot support these amendments, which are a clever way around the original proposal. Obviously, what is missing from the list in amendment No.5 is the words `a trade union'. The list contains just about everybody else. As I said, this is just a way to try to bypass the intent of the Bill. We cannot support that. In his evidence to the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures, Phillip Adams made the distinction that it is very hard to define what is a kosher community group that ought to be included under this third party definition and might be given access to free time. Regrettably, it is impossible to do this, and that is why we cannot support the amendments.

—I would like to respond to Senator Kernot. The crucial point is that the Australian Democrats are making a value judgment in supporting the charitable organisations but are saying no to industry and commerce. The political message is already banned in the advertising. So all we are doing is allowing these people to put their message before the community. I think the Democrats' attitude is totally unreasonable. I cannot see why the Democrats can be opposed to such a reasonable proposition. It is certainly not meant to be clever.
—It's tricky. It's a clever little trick.
—It is not meant to be clever. Senator Kernot might see it as clever. It is meant to be fair and reasonable. If she thinks being fair and reasonable is clever, she should think again.

—The Government opposes the Opposition's amendments. The first point I make—I will do this calmly—is that we are dealing with a very selective exemption provision. It is interesting to note that the Opposition wants to exempt from a ban professional and industry organisations and chambers of commerce. But nowhere in the amendments is there an exemption for community based organisations such as the ACA or others which have, as has been alleged in recent days, hijacked government.

para.tab: To allow one part of the community to advertise is to take a very selective and discriminatory approach. It excludes not only the community based groups that I mention, but also the trade union movement. I think those who actually framed this amendment should be ashamed of themselves, but I am quite sure, looking at Senator Kemp, that they would not be. I am not suggesting that he has framed it, of course. I am sure he would have had other people do that.

talk.start.para: —I did not insult Senator Kemp. But I think it is a very selective and a very cheeky amendment to put at this stage. It is outrageous, in fact.

para.tab: In relation to Senator Parer's quite legitimate assertion on amendment No. 4, as proposed by the Opposition, the Government has chosen the word `explicitly' for good reasons. I think honourable senators would understand that there was a campaign based on the charitable organisations at the time the Bill was first tabled. A very valid and strong point made by them was that they wanted to pursue social issues, whether issues of poverty or whatever. Because of that, we have limited our amendment No. 10 to paragraph 95A(3)(b) to explicit advertisements advocating a particular result in an election, as opposed to a more general prohibition which would have meant that advertisements run by the charitable, public and the like organisations would not have been allowed to canvass issues which were very close to those organisations.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —I want to delay the Committee briefly because I think this is the appropriate time to raise a question that I am very concerned about in relation to the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. It concerns the prevention of organisations, such as unions, from responding to what might be contained in a policy speech. To give an example—the chamber should bear in mind that we are talking down the track for State governments, ultimately—a particular government in its policy speech announces that it will, if elected, extend trading into Sundays. If legislation such as this were operating in that State, it would prevent the unions which have members in shops, or indeed the small retailers, from putting their points of view by way of advertisement over the electronic media. This would be so, despite the fact that the political party would have free time on the television for its policy launch and despite the fact that the talking heads of that particular political party could constantly repeat their reasons for advancing this policy of extending trading into Sundays, which would vitally affect the unions with members in particular shops and vitally affect small shopkeepers.

para.tab: I had to get that off my chest at this stage. I declare an interest in the matter, of course, because I am President of the Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Association in my State. I felt that the Committee would not mind my taking this opportunity to get that matter before it in the hope that it may be considered.

speech.speaker: Parer Sen W.R.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: 6.Clause 6, pages 7 to 9, proposed sections 95C and 95D, line 16 (page 7) to line 27 (page 9), omit the sections.

This amendment seeks to omit proposed sections 95C and 95D, which would remove the States and Territories from the jurisdiction of the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. We have taken the view that this is a Federal Bill which should apply to Federal elections, not to State and Territory elections. I understand that neither the Government nor the Australian Democrats intend to support this amendment. I just make the point that if debate on the Bill had not been guillotined, we would have proceeded to divide on this and would naturally have supported this amendment.

talk.start.para: —The amendment to clause 6, pages 7 and 9, is of such fundamental importance that I want to say a few words in support of my colleague Senator Parer. It is one thing for the Commonwealth to impose these strictures upon its own elections, that is, that there can be no paid electronic advertising and that there be this so-called limited free television, but it is an entirely different thing for the Commonwealth to seek to impose the same restrictions upon elections in the States. I know that there has been some debate around the corridors as to whether this is beyond the constitutional competence of the Commonwealth.
—That will be tested.

—As my colleague says, it will no doubt be tested in due course. But apart from that constitutional argument, it seems to be wrong in principle. I cannot see why the Commonwealth would see it as its role or its responsibility to prohibit electronic advertising in relation to a State election or a local government election, because I think this Bill, if I understand it correctly, Minister, does that also.

para.tab: The Government may have an argument for seeking to extend the coverage of the Commonwealth to affect State and local government elections in this way, but I cannot see what it is. I cannot see that it is any business of the Commonwealth's whatsoever. I support the amendment moved by Senator Parer, which would effectively exclude the States from the coverage of this Bill and allow them to deal with the question of their own electoral advertising laws without being concerned with meddling by Commonwealth Government.

speech.speaker: Walters Sen M.S.

talk.start.para: —Senator Hill has already spoken on Opposition amendment No. 6 concerning political advertising not being broadcast during State elections. But Professor Leslie Zines, a leading constitutional lawyer, has pointed out a serious problem with the Government's legislation, and it relates to section 106 of the Constitution. Section 106 provides:

speech.para: . . . the Constitution of each State of the Commonwealth shall, subject to this Constitution, continue as at the establishment of the Commonwealth, or as at the admission or establishment of the State, as the case may be, until altered in accordance with the Constitution of the State.

Although this provision has not been subject to extensive judicial interpretation, Professor Zines says that it may be arguable that the States' electoral systems constitute part of their Constitutions and, therefore, any attempt to encroach on this area would represent a breach of section 106 of the Commonwealth Constitution.

para.tab: I ask the Minister: has the Government studied section 106 and had a legal interpretation of the likelihood of a breach of that section of the Constitution by this amendment?

talk.start.para: —The Government developed the Bill in the light of constitutional legal advice, and we are quite confident that it will stand any constitutional challenge. As I mentioned earlier today—or at some stage in the last 24 hours—already there has been an indication by Mr Greiner that he would look to challenging the legislation. We are quite confident that the legislation will sustain any such challenge. At the time Nick Greiner made the announcement that the legislation would be challenged, he said, in colourful terms, that it was an outside bet that he would get the case up. My understanding is that it would be more than an outside bet.
—I asked the Minister whether the Government had had legal advice on section 106.

—I cannot canvass the details of the legal advice, but essentially the advice concerned whether the legislation would be able to withstand any constitutional challenge. Without going back to the advice, I cannot say that section 106, section 51 or whatever was canvassed, but the advice was very lengthy and made it very clear to us that the legislation would have no constitutional impediment.

—In order not to delay the Committee too much, as I did spend some time on this matter in my contribution in the second reading debate, I will speak briefly. I think it is quite appalling that this Government, which is noted for its centralism—of course, the Democrats have also been noted for their centralism over the years—has total disregard for the Federal system and the benefits of a Federal system. I reiterate very briefly what I have suggested to the Senate: if we create one electoral system for the whole of Australia and that electoral system is a mistake, we end up with one big disaster. It is a lot better to have a little disaster here and there in the States and allow a bit of experimentation.

—Senator Sherry obviously is a unique Tasmanian who does not support a Federal system. I have had consultations with a number of State parliamentarians in the last day or two. It is quite clear that many of them, if not all, have no idea of what the Federal Government is about to visit upon them. Very few State parliamentarians to whom I have spoken—and I must admit I think one of them was even a member of the Labor Party—have any idea of the consequences to be visited upon them.

para.tab: Most of the public debate has concentrated on issues relating to time limitations, free time and so forth. Those people in the States have not had a chance to realise what will be visited upon them. Again, it is a reflection upon the Democrats and the Government, who have sought to guillotine this debate, thus preventing those people from understanding the ramifications of what is about to happen.

I want to record my sincere regret that within the first 18 months of my serving in the Senate such a gross violation of States rights is to occur. I am glad to have had the support of Senator Hill, Senator Parer, Senator Walters and other honourable senators in the chamber tonight, but clearly this matter could have been dealt with in relation to Commonwealth elections alone. Broadcasts over the airwaves can easily be limited to State boundaries. The airwaves do, of course, go to particular regions, but there is no argument in a technical sense that this could not be applied purely to the Commonwealth.

Of course, this is another excuse for this centralist socialist Government to grab more power from the States. The Senate was designed by the founding fathers to stop that centralist trend. This Government and the Labor Party are committed to that centralism. This part of the Bill is just another part of an ongoing and very unfortunate trend in Australian politics, which I will certainly seek to reverse during my time in this place.

talk.start.para: —I want Senator Kernot to listen to what I have to say. If what is proposed includes the States, which I understand it does, and someone will correct me if I am wrong, and if the procedure of allowing 40 per cent for the Government, 40 per cent for the Opposition and 10 per cent for the rest is applied, in Queensland the Liberal Party, which is not the official Opposition but which gets more primary votes than the National Party, which is the primary Opposition—I use this because it is an example—
—Percentage of votes is important. It's one of the criteria.
—It's different in Queensland.

—For the record, I should say that the Democrats are telling me that it will be different in Queensland. It will depend on the overall percentage of votes. In that instance, because the Liberal Party gets, say, 25 per cent of the vote—I am not sure of my figures—and the National Party gets 23 per cent of the vote, the Liberal Party gets 40 per cent of the time. As we are not in a coalition, we are not in opposition together, that means the Liberal Party, with 25 per cent of the vote, gets 40 per cent of the time; and the National Party, with one per cent less, say, gets 10 per cent shared with anyone else—say, the Democrats.

para.tab: Perhaps I should ask the Minister about this. The same procedure would apply to the National Party and the Liberal Party in Western Australia and I suspect it would apply to the Greens in Tasmania. Certainly in Queensland, which is the State I am familiar with, it would apply. This could be an enormously anomalous situation. I ask the Minister to explain that. It could be quite an outrageous situation in Queensland.

talk.start.para: —The first point I will make is in response to a matter Senator Campbell raised. It would be federalism gone wild if the Federal Government were to abdicate or refer over its broadcasting power. What we are proposing to do is not out of the ordinary in terms of the degree of regulation that already exists in broadcasting. It has been and is a Federal power that we are talking about, one that has been traditionally and constitutionally exercised—and rightly so—by the Federal Government and that is exactly what we are doing here.

para.tab: The legislation makes it quite clear that there is an apportionment of time, as Senator Macdonald indicated. The ABT would make assessments as to the final outcome of the allocation of time within each individual State. There is capacity within the legislation for that to happen. That time would be apportioned in accordance with the formula as set out in the proposed legislation.

talk.start.para: —Can you point out the section please, Minister.

—I will come to that section in a minute. Proposed section 95DD(1) gives the Tribunal the power to determine and to grant a period of free time. Proposed section 95DD(1)(a) prescribes a period of free time for the Government, 95DD(1)(b) for the Opposition, and 95DD(1)(c) for other parties represented. So proposed section 95DD and thereafter are the enabling provisions for both regulations in the Broadcasting Tribunal to determine in accordance with the Act. interject.para: Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations
POLITICAL BROADCASTS AND POLITICAL DISCLOSURES BILL 1991

We confirm that today we met with Sir Maurice Byers Q.C., former Solicitor General for the Commonwealth, to discuss with him proposed amendments to the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991.

The amendments discussed with Sir Maurice related to proposals to amend the Broadcasting Act 1942 by modifying the proposed moratorium on the broadcast of political advertising and providing for a system of freetime election broadcasts. Under proposed Section 95DK of the Broadcasting Act, broadcasters will be compelled to allocate units of freetime (an undefined term) for the purposes of making election broadcasts during the relevant election period for the person to whom time has been granted. Under proposed Clause 95DK(5), a broadcaster is required to make that election broadcast free of charge.

Proposed Section 95DK(7) provides that licensees required to make election broadcasts have an entitlement to such additional broadcasting time to broadcast other material (including advertisements and station promotions) as is determined by the regulations.
In summary, Sir Maurice Byers views were as follows:
(a)Section 95DK is invalid because it is inconsistent with the protective guarantee of just terms in Section 51(31) of the Constitution.

(b)Even if the law could be categorised as being one with respect to the power granted by Section 51(5) of the Constitution (that is, a law with respect to "postal, telegraphic, telephonic and other like services") it would be invalid because "the effect of the purpose of paragraph (31) with its requirement for `just terms', in Section 51 is that other heads of power, including the incidental power" do not authorise legislation for the acquisition of property: the
Tasmanian Dam Case
(1983) 158 CLR 1, 282.
(c)Commercial television licensees have the right to sell time, without restriction, during a 24 hour day and that right is property for the purposes of Section 51(31) of the Constitution.

(d)The question whether just terms had been provided would turn on whether an allowance of extra advertising or promotional time per hour was practicable: if it was not practicable then the acquisition would be unfair. If the acquisition was unfair then it would not be on "just terms".

In addition, Sir Maurice expressed the preliminary view that the Bill as a whole is inconsistent with the system of responsible Government envisaged by the Constitution, in particular, the free flow of information to electors. In his view, any law regulating elections that may have the effect of restricting the electorate's access to information may be unconstitutional.
Should you have any questions please do not hesitate to telephone Ian McGill of this office.
