speech.para: The purpose of this amendment is to ensure that those parties which would be excluded from putting in a return for a particular financial year in respect of contributions to a political party or a branch of a party should be in legislation and not in regulation. My understanding is that in the other place it was the so-called Kerin amendment, if I am correct, that changed this to a matter of regulation rather than legislation. The Opposition has a lot of concerns about that.

para.tab: The Opposition is also concerned about the fact that the point relating to the amount of money above which a disclosure had to be made has been removed. Whereas previously it had been $1,000, the Government itself recommended, about 12 months ago, that the figure be $1,500. Then, Mr Chairman, it disappeared altogether. So our recommendation is that this clause be amended so that it brings back the regulations in regard to organisations and nominates the amount above which disclosure has to be made as $1,500.

talk.start.para: —Through you, Mr Chairman, I ask the Minister whether it is correct that one of the problems with the Opposition's amendment is that it could well lead us to the disclosure of membership lists.

—Mr Chairman, in responding to this I will go through a little history. It was initially the Government's intention to have a minimum benchmark under which contributions would not be disclosable. But we considered that and we also considered whether we should just have a blanket compulsion on disclosure. The problem we confronted was that we needed to provide flexibility. The only way that we felt we could do that was to provide for regulation making exclusions from the blanket disclosure provision. Those provisions—-
—Why the flexibility?

—I will explain that in a second. The reason why the Government felt that was so was that there are a number of things that parties do and expend moneys on that they really would not want to have included in an overall package of disclosure; for instance, buying pencils, rubbers and other stationery is one level. One could say that could be accommodated by a benchmark.

para.tab: The other problem we found was—and this was a problem that actually generated a lot of heat in Victoria—that it was felt that with a blanket disclosure provision parties would have to disclose all subscriptions, donations, gifts, et cetera to them, and in the process would have to disclose the membership lists of those organisations because they would be a contribution to the party. Those have been the two motivating concerns in respect to providing for exemption from disclosure. The regulation, as it is intended, will cover only those two types of areas. As I say, those regulations would be disallowable by this place. But it was very much born out of a concern that if one had a blanket provision then one would compel all contributors' names to be disclosed and, in that respect, membership names would be disclosed.

The question which I suppose may be asked is: if one has an exemption level of, say, $1,500, does that not cater for the membership and the minor expenditure and income arrangements? The answer is that it does but only to a certain extent. The concern was that one could very well start up a $5,000 club or a $10,000 club or a $1,501 club which could be seen to be given special membership. It might be, as Senate Olsen and I would know in respect of our football club back in Adelaide, that one could have a membership of a special class who pay a certain amount of money, whether it be $1,000 or whatever.

talk.start.para: —All members of the Labor Party.
—We do not have that many, but we still get to the grand final, which is better than Senator Hill's team. They may all be members of the Labor party—all but our No. 1 member.

para.tab: But there is a concern that by, for instance, just excluding membership fees by legislation there could be rorts on the definition of the term `membership fee', and membership of parts of an organisation could be dependent on the payment of a large amount of money. Therefore, we have not chosen to exclude by legislation membership fees, which is one of the motivating factors towards having this regulatory provision. Nor have we chosen to put a benchmark as hard as the $1,500 which is included in Senator Parer's amendment.

As I say, our intention is to ensure, firstly, that those extremely minor amounts of money do not have to be disclosed and, secondly, that membership, bona fide or otherwise, is tackled to the extent that bona fide memberships are non-disclosable to the extent of the name of the person who is a member, but non-bona fide memberships are disclosable. In terms of bona fide memberships, a party would have to disclose the cumulative figure of membership. There is no debate about that. The other thing about this particular point is that the regulations would have to come back here and they would not operate in this instance, in respect of the disclosure provisions of the Act, unless the last date allowable for their disallowance had expired.

The motivation is very much to make the provisions work to that extent. That is why the Government has chosen to give some regulatory power. As I say—I know Senator Kemp is looking at me inquisitively—the exercise of that power would be very much under the control of either House of Parliament.

talk.start.para:
—
In the early part of the Minister's comments he mentioned clubs which may be $5,000 clubs or even $10,000 clubs. Is the Minister saying that if we had those types of clubs they would be included or excluded under the regulations which the Government is contemplating?

—What I am saying is that those sorts of clubs would be included. Donations to those sorts of clubs would be disclosable as donations to the organisation that those particular clubs are either part of or channel money through. The club would become a third party. The intention is not to allow a mechanism through which the intention of the Act would be applied. The distinction I was making was between bona fide party membership and the artificial structure of gilt-edged clubs around a party organisation. In the latter case one would want them disclosed but in the former one would not. That is why the flexibility has been provided for.

—It seems logical to me that if we are talking only about bona fide members, it would be easy rather than difficult to set a limit. I cannot see how, if we set a limit at, say, $1,500 or $2,000, we could possibly pick up other groups which the Government may wish to have excluded.

—I tried to go through the processes of explaining this. The reason we did not choose a figure of $1,500 was in recognition of the fact that quite often one might not have donations of less than $1,500 that one would want to disclose. Keeping that in mind, quite often there are donations of less than $1,500 that one may not want to disclose because they relate to the purchase of paper or whatever. That is why we have not gone for a hard and fast number.

para.tab: The other thing I asked the Committee to keep in mind was the fact that we are, in this package, introducing the capacity in the Electoral Commission for spot audit. To the extent that any organisation tries to avoid the disclosure provisions, the Electoral Commission would have the capacity to comprehensively spot audit a registered political party or a third party organisation. As a consequence, we are quite confident that, with those spot audit powers and the extent of those powers, any evasive action would be tagged by the Commission.

Basically what this does, as I said earlier, is provide some degree of flexibility in making the section operable in a way that does not mean that, on the one hand, a bona fide organisation has to disclose stuff that we do not need and, on the other hand, the Electoral Commission is preoccupied with vetting accounts that it otherwise would not vet. The basic point is that those regulations that determine what is and what is not would come to the Parliament and would be disallowable.

talk.start.para: —I emphasise the point that we are talking about contributions or payments of $1,500 by a particular political party. If a political party buys typewriter ribbons, pencils or whatever, obviously it does not have to disclose that payment to the Commission because it is under the set amount. Likewise, in the area revenue and receipt of contributions, if a party received membership fees under the set figure of $1,500, it would not be obliged to provide the membership list. So I put to the Committee that the view of the Minister that this legislation would require membership lists to be placed before us is an absolute furphy. The Government has set the figure at $1,500 and the amounts below that therefore do not form part of the list and rightfully so.

para.tab: A range of expenditure items of major political parties has been identified. It is logical and sensible to note that one would not want a detailed list of, for example, the number of pencils and pens that a political party buys. The other point to be made in refuting what the Minister had to say and supporting the amendment is that surely we, on a matter of this importance, ought to be incorporating in legislation what those amounts ought to be so that any political party or government in the future would have to reintroduce legislation to the Parliament if it wanted to alter the figures. That is a very important point in my view. We are dealing with legislation which will operate in the future. It is the province of the Parliament, not the province of Executive Council, to do this. I think that very important principle ought to be embodied in this legislation.

talk.start.para: —I will respond very briefly to that. I think Senator Olsen has been in parliaments long enough to know that regulations are endorsed or disallowed by parliament and that Executive Councils have to operate in that context.

para.tab: There are two other problems that we have with the Opposition's proposal. The Opposition has put in line two of proposed section 311A(1) a requirement that a return be furnished within four weeks after the end of each financial year. I think it is very strongly felt that the eight week period that we have in our legislation is more appropriate. It gives the organisations involved a degree of time which may be necessary.

When one looks at the enormity of the penalties that are involved when one lodges annual returns of income and expenditure and when one looks at the fact that in so many of the those cases there is the element of strict liability, I think one can see that one has to be fair and give the parties the extra four weeks in which to lodge their returns. As I say, there are some enormous penalties here. Under the Constitution, a person who breaches some of these penalties would be denied the ability ever to stand for parliament. I think it is important to have that eight week period.

Under paragraph (a) of proposed section 311A(1) there is a requirement for the lodging of returns with respect to `the political party or branch'. I do not know whether that means State branch or whether that means every minor sub branch that may be in operation. I think there is a degree of confusion as to that particular term, which does present a problem.

Our alternative ensures that the political party lodges a return and, by and with the capacity for spot audit, branches are picked up whether they be State branches or others. But, as I say, when one is talking about an enormous weight of penalties that accrue, I do not think we should really allow any scope for vagueness as to this particular provision.

talk.start.para: —The Opposition would have no objections to going from four to eight weeks.
—What do you want to do with the word `branch'?
—What was your proposal?

—There is no proposal. I am sticking to my alternative which does not include the words `or branch'. The point that I made was that those terms can be vague. They could refer to either a State branch or an individual sub-branch, wherever it might be—whether it is in Ceduna or Townsville or wherever. I think there is no need to have that sort of specificity in the provision. First, the term `political party' encompasses the broad structure of the party. Secondly, I do not think we should allow for vagueness when the penalties involve, in some instances, disqualification from parliament for anyone who offends.

talk.start.para: —I cannot envisage a situation where the problem that the Minister refers to might arise, because the proposed new section is fairly specific. It says:

talk.start.para: —I seek clarification of the Minister's suggestion. Do I take it that the figure of $1,500 would be set in legislation, that amounts received above $1,500 would be disclosed, that amounts under $1,500 would not be disclosed on the revenue side, but that on the payments side the requirement for disclosure or otherwise for amounts under $1,500 would be set by regulation?

—It is the reverse of what the Opposition is doing. It would exempt anything under $1,500. I am saying that everything over $1,500 would automatically, instantly, be disclosed. talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 October 1991:

para.tab: With reference to applications to the Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC) for withdrawal of funds by persons not yet entitled by having reached a prescribed age:
(1) What policy guidelines have been given by the Treasurer to the ISC?
(2) Has any instruction been given by the Treasurer or by the ISC itself to delay the processing of such applications?
(3) What is the normal time lapse between receipt of an application and advice to the applicant of the outcome of the application?
(4) Are applicants provided with detailed reasons if an application is declined; if so, when?
(5) Was there an increase in applications during the financial year 1990-91?
(6) Does the Treasurer have evidence of a further increase in such applications during the current financial year?
(7) How many applications were made and/or approved in the financial years (a) 1990-91; and (b) 1991-92 (to date)?

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) Under the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations, certain benefits must generally be preserved until a member has attained 55 years of age and has retired from employment. Subject to the conditions of the relevant trust deed, such benefits may be paid out earlier than retirement on or after age 55 in the event of the member's death, permanent incapacity for work, permanent departure from Australia or in such other circumstances as the Commissioner considers appropriate.

When the ISC was established and took over some of the superannuation functions of the Taxation Office, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner took the view that related Taxation Rulings should continue to apply until such time as they were reviewed and amended by the ISC. One such ruling was IT2335.

These provisions are similar to those previously in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 (the Tax Act). To enable consistent consideration of ``other circumstances'' for the early release of preserved benefits, the Commissioner of Taxation provided guidance in the form of ruling IT2335.

That ruling generally restricts the release of benefits to cases where it is established that the member has incurred expenses through sickness, accident or other misfortune beyond his or her control and which would cause severe financial hardship if paid by the member from sources other than amounts withdrawn from the fund.

With the relocation of the former Tax Act provisions into the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations, effective from 1 July 1990, it was necessary to review those rulings as to their continued applicability. As a result of this review, and to encompass changing circumstances and legislation, the ISC is currently developing new guidelines for the early release of superannuation benefits which are preserved under the Occupational Superannuation Standards.
(2) Neither the Treasurer nor the ISC has issued instructions to delay the processing of release of benefit applications.
On the contrary, both the Treasurer and the ISC regard such applications as requiring urgent assessment and, accordingly, they are given priority.

Additional resources, substantial in terms of the resources available to the ISC, have been applied to deal with the increase in volume of applications received recently. This has been at the expense of other functions.

In addition, the ISC is investigating the feasibility of changes in procedures to speed up review of applications, including the possibility of fund trustees sharing the responsibility for reviewing them.

(3) Generally, if all information is correctly submitted, the time lapse between receipt of an application and advice to the applicant of the outcome is 10 working days. More difficult cases may take up to 15 working days to complete.
(4) If an applicant's request for early release of superannuation benefits is declined, reasons for the decision are provided to the applicant in a letter advising the applicant of the outcome.

Should an applicant request a review of a decision not to release the superannuation benefit and the release is again declined, a further explanation is provided in a letter informing the applicant of the result of the review.
(5) The ISC experienced a significant increase in the number of requests made for early release of superannuation benefits during the 1990-91 financial year.
A total of 4,692 release applications were received during the 1989-90 financial year. This increased to 11,618 applications in the 1990-91 financial year.
(6) The increase in the number of release applications received by the ISC has continued into the current financial year.
During the period July to October 1991, a total of 7,286 applications were received.
(7) (a) of the 11,618 applications received during the 1990-91 financial year, approximately 75% were approved.
(b) of the 7,286 applications received during the period July to October 1991, approximately 75% were approved.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 16 October 1991:

para.tab: In light of the recent announcement of lower sugar import quotas by the United States of America and low commodity prices and the serious implications for sugar growers in Australia, what is the Government doing to assist those growers.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: The US reduction of the global sugar tariff quota is an extremely disappointing development for Australia especially as it comes on top of restraints placed on Australian meat exports to the US and the US-EC grain subsidy war. The cut in the quota is also clearly inconsistent with the US espoused position in the GATT Uruguay Round of trade negotiations.

The sugar industry is not alone amongst rural industries in experiencing the effects of depressed international prices and also the effects of the current drought. The current rural downturn is being caused largely by overproduction in world agricultural markets, combined with the effects of export subsidies and other protection arrangements in a number of countries, notably the EC, the USA and Japan. The Australian Government is committed to improving the international trading environment and will persist in efforts in the Uruguay Round of GATT Trade Negotiations, and through other opportunities, to achieve enduring and beneficial reform.

Australia has put much effort into achieving progress in the Uruguay Round negotiations and will continue to do so. The negotiations are now entering a critical phase and the Government is taking every opportunity to exert pressure on the major participants to achieve meaningful reforms.

Within the domestic economy, the Government has maintained its commitment to the process of microeconomic reform and has introduced a range of measures to ease the current difficulties while continuing to build a more efficient and prosperous economy. These measures include lower tariffs across the board, changes to taxation arrangements, improved anti-dumping and countervailing arrangements and the phasing out of certain developing country preferences. This will mean lower input costs and greater competitiveness for the primary sector.

The Government believes that assistance through the Rural Adjustment Scheme (RAS) is an efficient way of targeting assistance to those farmers who really need it. It deals even handedly with individual farming families and provides a very effective use of limited Commonwealth funds.

The Government recently announced increased funding for the Commonwealth's Rural Assistance Package by a further $30.64 million. The structural adjustment component of the RAS or Part A (which includes farm improvement and debt reconstruction measures) will receive $95.47 million in 1991-92. The Commonwealth's contribution to Part B of RAS will be $23.67 million which will provide assistance to farmers to obtain carry-on finance for a period of up to two years. The Commonwealth/State contribution ratio has changed from 1:1 to 2:1, to encourage the States to fully implement Part B. $40 million has been allocated to Part C of RAS to provide income support and re-establishment grants to farmers without prospects.

In addition, a further $30 million will be provided over the next 2 years, for the provision of income support to assist farmers who have long term prospects but who cannot carry more debt, even with the interest subsidies provided under RAS.

The 1991 Federal Budget contained a range of measures designed to help people living in rural areas and facing hardship in the economic downturn. Key components of the Budget include revised eligibility rules for Family Allowance Supplements, assistance through AUSTUDY and the Assistance for Isolated Children Scheme, and increased funding for the Rural Counselling Program. Two new schemes, the Business Advisers for Rural Areas (BARA) Scheme and the Rural Industries Business Extension Service (RIBES) have been introduced to assist in the economic development of rural areas.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 November 1991:

para.tab: (1) Have any changes been made to the regulations that allow Army Reservists to take an option to go on periods of full-time duty.
(2) What are the nature of these changes.
(3) Is the option still available to Army Reservists to serve up to 100 days on full-time duty.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) No changes have been made to the regulations that allow Army Reservists to take an option to go on periods of full-time duty, or as it is correctly known, full-time service. Implementation of these regulations has been tightened to approve full-time duty for Army Reservists only in circumstances where there is an operational requirement. This implementation allows Army Reservists to be employed in the most important areas within budgetary guidance. Army Reservists who volunteer to participate in Regular Army exercises overseas, such as the recent exchange of personnel with the United Kingdom, continue to be placed on full-time service.
(2) As previously mentioned there are no changes to current regulations covering full-time service.

(3) Under the Chief of the General Staff's current determination for periods of training, Army Reservists may serve up to, but not more than, 100 days. This service can be either non-continuous, that is short periods such as week nights and week ends, or in an unbroken period, or as a mixture of both. For full-time service Army Reservists may be employed for up to two years; longer periods would normally require the member to apply for transfer to the Regular Army.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 November 1991:

para.tab: With reference to the department's stock of international maps:
(1) Are the majority of maps out of date and effectively useless.
(2) What proportion of the maps are older than three years.
(3) How old were the maps of Iraq and Kuwait the department held before the invasion of Kuwait.
(4) With reference to hydrographic survey mapping, is it correct that Defence has a 16-year backlog in producing charts for priority areas as defined in the Dibb report; if not, what is the backlog.
(5) Is the level of charting in Torres Strait insufficient to allow full level manoeuvres.
(6) Would there be a risk involved of losing a patrol boat in a low level threat in the Torres Strait, because the level of charting is not adequate for a patrol boat.

(7) With reference to the 1987 Dibb report comment that the current state of charting and marine environmental knowledge of nearby areas of strategic importance to Australia is less than satisfactory, what impact will the decommissioning of HMAS COOK, the oceanographic survey ship, have on the backlog of priority mapping.
(8) Are any private firms charting waters in Australia's strategic area of interest; is so, what are the names of the firms and what areas are they charting.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

para.tab: (1) In general the ADF only holds sufficient numbers of international maps for planning purposes, relying on exchange agreements with our principal allies for bulk stocks should the need arise. Under these exchange agreements the ADF is routinely provided with copies of the latest edition maps and aeronautical charts at scales smaller than 1:250000. Maps at larger scales may be available on request, however, third party caveats may preclude some of these requests being met.

In an area of rapid development a map can be "out of date" even before it is published, while in other areas where no development has occurred a map may remain fully up to date and current for many years. The age of a map is therefore not necessarily an accurate guide to its usefulness.
(2) The majority of the international maps held are between three and ten years old. All are the latest editions and therefore the best available.

(3) The maps held by the ADF prior to the invasion of Kuwait were the latest editions and were between one and six years old. In addition to the conventional mapping held, Army produced a satellite image map based on commercially available imagery acquired during 1990.

(4) The RAN Hydrographic Service is responsible for both the national and defence requirement for nautical charts. This will eventually entail the production and maintenance of 736 charts covering an internationally agreed area of Australian responsibility (which is larger than the area defined in the Dibb report). Production to date has resulted in the issue of 320 charts with the remainder estimated to take a further 20 years to complete.

(5) Approximately 60% of the area of Torres Strait is either unsurveyed or inadequately surveyed. However, major shipping routes passing through the strait are well surveyed and charted to modern standards: operations can be conducted safely within these areas. All charts of the area clearly reflect the state of the surveys and indicate those areas inadequately covered.

(6) There will always be a risk in operating in inadequately charted areas, however, daylight operations are possible using established procedures for coral or poorly charted waters. Night operations would entail a greater risk, which would apply equally to any contacts of interest in the area.
Within the well surveyed 40% of the Strait the risk would be low and comparable to normal peacetime operations.
(7) HMAS COOK was an oceanographic, rather than a hydrographic, survey vessel. It therefore did not contribute to the nautical charting programme.

Prior to decommissioning, HMAS COOK was being used primarily as a research vessel in support of DSTO and although there was some value to Navy in the work being conducted it was considered that this was not commensurate with the outlay involved.

(8) There are no private firms conducting hydrographic surveys for charting purposes within Australia's area of interest. Some firms are conducting surveys for offshore construction and resource exploitation, with some of the data being passed to the Hydrographic Service either spontaneously or on request.

(2) Would such potential co-operation extend to all information made available to Australia during the 1970s when it received correspondence emanating from the TTCP Technology Liaison Group, which covered biological defence, and to relevant information which Australia currently receives from TTCP Subgroup E; if not, why not.

para.tab: (1) Yes.

The information contained herein may be used and disseminated for national defence purposes only within the recipient governments and their national defence contractors. The recipient governments shall ensure that any other use or disclosure of the information is made only with the prior written consent of each of the above governments."

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 11 November 1991:

para.tab: With reference to claims made in `Pierpont' in The Bulletin on 5 November 1991 that companies are producing tins of foodstuffs and claiming they are Australian when the contents may contain up to 80 percent of imported ingredients:
(1) What are the terms under which companies may sell foodstuffs stating they are made in Australia.
(2) Are Australian export standards higher than those for imports.
(3) Is it a fact that there are 300 inspectors to examine exports out of Australia but only 100 examining imports into Australia.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) The mandatory labelling of foodstuffs sold in Australia is a State and Territory responsibility. I understand that most States and Territories have adopted the Australian Food Standards Code, which is now the responsibility of the National Food Authority. The labelling of export foodstuffs is controlled by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service under the Export Control Act 1982.

Internationally, the Joint FAO/WHO Codex Alimentarius Commission has established a general standard for the labelling of food and that standard states that when a food undergoes processing which changes its nature in a second country, the country in which the processing is performed shall be considered to be the country of origin.

The Export Control Act 1982, and I understand the various State and Territory food laws, stipulate that unless foods undergo some form of treatment which alters their basic nature, they cannot be labelled as being of Australian origin. This follows the international convention.

The Pierpont article in the Bulletin of 5 November 1991 specifically refers to fruit juice and I am informed that most States and Territories have adopted, or are in the process of adopting, a provision requiring the use of imported juice to be declared on the label.

(2) Foodstuffs imported into Australia have to meet the standards set by the States and Territories in their food laws. These laws generally reflect the provisions in the Australian Food Standards Code and it is the Code that is used in assessing imports where necessary. I am confident that these standards provide adequate protection to consumers.

As recognised in the Pierpont article Australia, as an exporting country, has to meet the demands of its customers. Under those circumstances there may be differences in the standards. From a quarantine perspective, Australian import standards are amongst the most stringent in the world.

The Pierpont article does not distinguish between the role of Customs and the food inspection role of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS). AQIS is responsible for the inspection and certification of most export food products and the majority of meat produced for domestic consumption. AQIS also administers the imported food inspection program which is based on a risk assessment of the public health dangers of the food in question against the Australian Food Standards Code. Additionally, AQIS inspects plant and animal products for export and import for quarantine purposes. To undertake these tasks AQIS has a staff of some 1788 inspectors plus some 700 State and Territory employees who work under contract to AQIS. The article also fails to recognise the number of State and Territory employees who are involved in the enforcement of domestic food laws.
The Customs Service has a monitoring role in respect of the clearance of imported and exported foods in close liaison with AQIS personnel.
